(SB 11.3.21) Next, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi explains the three divisions of the PurÄÅ†as. “tasmad gurum prapadyeta jijÃ±Äsuá¸¥ Å›reya uttamam 105Anuccheda 17 Three Divisions of the PurÄÅ†as 17.1 à¥§à¥­ | à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ (à¥«à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥§à¥¨à¥§-à¥§à¥¨à¥ª ) - FURTHERMORE, SKANDA PURÄ€Å…A states: à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤²à¤‚ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥¦ à¥¥ à¤¬à¤¿à¤­à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤²à¥à¤ª à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‹ à¤®à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤²à¤¯à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥ˆà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤²à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥§ à¥¥ à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤‰à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥ à¤¨ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥¨ à¥¥ à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦ à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¿à¤·à¤¦à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤œà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨ à¤š à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥© à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ O best of the twice-born, I consider the meaning of the PuraÅ†as to be as immutable as that of the Vedas. Without doubt, all of the Vedas are firmly established in the Puranas. Long ago, the personified Veda became apprehensive of those whose acquain- tance with her is insufficient, and she thought, “This sort of per- son will distort my meaning.” But then the Itihasas and PurÄÅ†as helped the Veda by firmly establishing her meaning. What can- not be found in the Vedas, O brÄhmanas, is found in the Smrti, and what cannot be found in either is clearly explained in the PurÄÅ†as. O learned brahmanas, even if a person has studied the four Vedas along with the VedÃ¤ngas and Upanisads, he is not con- sidered learned unless he knows the Puranas. (Skanda PurÄá¹‡a, PrabhÄsa khanda 5.3.121-124 ) 1 1 vedavan niÅ›calam manye purÃ¤nÃ¤rtham dvijottamaá¸¥ 106 17 Three Divisions of the PurÄpas 17.2 à¤…à¤¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¤°à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿- à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤§à¤¿à¤—à¤® à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¶à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ Although the authority of the PurÄÅ†as has been established [in the previous anucchedas], still it is difficult for modern human beings of impoverished intellect to comprehend their ultimate meaning. The reasons for this difficulty are that the Puranas, like the Vedas, are only partially available and that the PurÄÅ†as generally tend to establish the supremacy of various deities. Thus, the same doubt [that was encountered with the Vedas ] remains in the case of the PurÄÅ†as. 17.3 à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡ (à¥«à¥© à¥¬à¥ª à¥¬à¥­-à¥¬à¥®) - As stated in Matsya Purana: à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤°à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥ª à¥¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤£à¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥« à¥¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¦à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥„à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥¬ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ A history is called a Purana if it has the five defining character- istics; otherwise, it is called an akhyÄna. The sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as (kalpas) primarily glorify ÅšrÄ« Hari; the rÄjasika PurÄnas, Lord Brahma; and the tamasika PurÄÅ†as, Lord Siva and Goddess vedaá¸¥ pratisthitaá¸¥ sarve purane natra samsayaá¸¥ bibhety alpa-Å›rutad vedo mam ayam cÄƒlayiá¹£yati itihasa-puranais tu niscalo’yam ká¹›tah purÄƒ yan na dá¹›á¹£á¹­am hi vedeÅŸu tad dá¹›á¹£á¹­am smrtiÈ™u dvijaá¸¥ ubhayor yan na dá¹›á¹£á¹­am hi tat puranaiá¸¥ pragiyate yo veda caturo vedÃ¤n sangopanisado dvijaá¸¥ puranam naiva jÄnÄti na ca sa syÃ¤d vicaká¹£aá¹‡aá¸¥ 107 II PramÄÅ†a Durga, along with Agni. The Puranas in the mixed gunas glorify Goddess Sarasvati and the forefathers (pitrs). (MP 53.64, 67-68)2 17.4 à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤°à¥Œ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤œà¥à¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤šà¥ à¤›à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ - à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‹à¤®à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤·à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ - à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤µà¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤•à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤²- à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥„à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¥ - “à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¥ƒà¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤ƒâ€ (à¤¬à¥ƒà¥¦à¥§ | à¥« | à¥§à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¤•à¤•à¤°à¥à¤®à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ In the above statement, the word agni (fire) refers to the Vedic sacrifices performed by offering oblations into various sacred fires. The conjunction ca (and) in the phrase sivasya ca implies the wife of Lord Siva [Goddess DurgÄ]. Sankirá¹‡eÅŸu (in the mixed) means “in the various Puranas in the mixed gunas of sattva, rajas, and tamas.” Here sarasvatyaá¸¥ (of Sarasvati) means “of the presid- ing deity of speech” and, by implication, “of the various deities referred to in the numerous scriptural texts she embodies.” The Åšruti affirms: “By ritualistic result-oriented action, one can attain the abode of the forefathers” (BAU 1.5.16). According to this statement, the word pitá¹›á¹‡Äm (of the forefathers) refers to the result-oriented rituals (Vedic karma) meant for attaining the planet of the forefathers. Commentary THE VERSE FROM MATSYA PURANA cited in Anuccheda 17.3 mentions five subjects that characterize a Purana. Another verse of Matsya PurÄÅ†a lists those subjects: 2 paÃ±cargatvaá¹ puranam syad Ã¤khyanam itarat smá¹›tam sÃ¤ttvikeÅŸu ca kalpesu mahatmyam adhikam hareá¸¥ rajaseÅŸu ca mahatmyam adhikaá¹ brahmano viduá¸¥ tadvad agnes ca mahatmyam tÄƒmaseÅŸu sivasya ca sankirneÅŸu sarasvatyah pitá¹›á¹‡am ca nigadyate karmanÄƒ pity-lokaá¸¥ 108 4 17 Three Divisions of the PurÄÅ†as The five subjects that characterize a Purana are creation, dissolu- tion, genealogy, the period of reign of the Manus, and the activi- ties of illustrious kings and enlightened sages appearing within the great dynasties. (MP 53.65)* Anucchedas 57 and 61 of Åšri Tattva Sandarbha discuss these five subjects in detail. In the verses cited in the text from Matsya PurÄÅ†a (Anuccheda 17.3), the word kalpa could mean a day of Brahma, or it could refer to a “scripture” or “Purana.” The various meanings of this word are listed in the Medini Sanskrit dictionary: Kalpa means “scripture,” “rule,” “logic,” “dissolution,” and “a day of Brahma.” (Medini 1.21.2)5 The word kalpa is translated here as Purana based upon the gloss of this word given by ÅšrÄ« RÄdhamohana GosvÄmi. Although the meaning of kalpa as “a day of Brahma” seems natural, it would be illogical to consider that some days of Brahma could be exclusively in sattva, rajas, or tamas. According to LBH 1.4.30, all avatÄras appear in every day of Brahma, and it seems that kalpas are similar in nature. The Puranas are divided according to the gunas of material nature that they embody. The list of the PurÄÅ†as belonging to each guna is given in Padma Purana: [Lord Siva said:] O beautiful lady, know that the ViÅŸÅ†u, Narada, Bhagavata, Garuda, Padma, and Varaha Puranas embody the per- spective born of sattva-guna (luminosity and being); the Brahma- nda, Brahma-vaivarta, MÃ¤rkandeya, Bhavisya, VÃ¤mana, and Brahma Puranas embody the perspective born of rajo-guna (dynamism and conditional becoming); and the Matsya, Kurma, Linga, Åšiva, Skanda, and Agni Puranas embody the perspective born of tamo- guna (ignorance and stasis). (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 236.18- 21) sargas ca pratisargaÅ› ca vamso manvantarÄÅ†i ca vamsyanucaritam caiva puranam paÃ±ca-laká¹£aá¹‡am “kalpa Å›Ästre vidhau nyaye samvarte brahmane dine “vaiá¹£á¹‡avaá¹ naradiyam ca tatha bhagavatam subham â†’ 109 II Pramana This statement makes it exceedingly clear that it is the PurÄÅ†as that are predominantly established in particular gunas. The verses ÅšrÄ«la Jiva cites from Skanda Purana imply that the PurÄÅ†as are as good as the Vedas and should be accepted as such by anyone who accepts the authority of the Vedas. There are many commentaries on the Vedas written by Vedic scholars, but the PurÄnas are the nat- ural commentary, because they were compiled by the very person who compiled the Vedas themselves, ÅšrÄ«la Vyasa. Therefore, even without directly studying the Vedas, one can understand their mes- sage by studying the Puranas alone. On the other hand, study of the Vedas in this age is incomplete without study of the PurÄÅ†as; therefore, studying the Puranas is even more appropriate and prac- tical for us than studying the Vedas. Furthermore, the statement from Skanda Purana quoted in Anuccheda 17.1 (i.e., that no one can be considered learned without studying the Puranas) suggests that the PurÄÅ†as are also more important than the ItihÄsas. But just as we meet with difficulties in studying the Vedas in this age, we also encounter difficulties in studying the Puranas. The eighteen major and eighteen minor PurÄnas constitute a vast body of literature, and there are no current disciplic successions or authentic commentaries for most of these works. Portions of some Puranas are not available, and other PurÄnas have variant readings and interpolations. As with the Vedas, independent study of the PurÄÅ†as yields no clear conclusion, because each PurÄÅ†a seems to establish a different deity as Supreme. Å iva Purana proclaims Lord Åšiva supreme, Visnu Purana proclaims ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u, and so on. For one who studies them without proper guidance, the result is confusion. Such a student will not know the distinctions between the worship of Åšiva, ViÅŸÅ†u, Devi, or some other deity. 110 garuá¸am ca tatha pÃ¤dmaá¹ vÃ¤rÃ¤ham subha-darÅ›ane sÃ¤ttvikÄni purÄá¹‡Äni vijÃ±eyÄni subhÄni vai brahmandam brahma-vaivartam mÃ¤rkandeyaá¹ tathaiva ca bhaviá¹£yam vamanam brahmam rajasani nibodha me matsyam kaurmaá¹ tatha laingam saivam skÃ¤ndam tathaiva ca agneyam ca saá¸ etani tamasÃ¤ni nibodha me 17 Three Divisions of the Puranas ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« offers a solution to this problem in the next anuccheda. 111 Anuccheda 18 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Fulfills the Criteria of Authority in the Matter of Ultimate Truth 18.1 à¥§à¥® à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤•à¤¥à¤¾à¤®à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¾ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥‡à¤¤à¤°à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ ? à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¥ â€œà¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤à¥à¤œà¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥” (à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¥§à¥ªà¥¤à¥§à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ â€œà¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤®à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¬à¤²à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ THIS BEING THE CASE [that the PurÄnas embody different gunas of primordial nature], Matsya Purana classifies the various well- known PurÄÅ†as into three divisions based specifically on the descriptions that they contain. But how can we determine the relative importance of the PurÄÅ†as so that we can then learn about the other subjects under discussion [namely, sambandha, abhidheya, and prayojana]? If we use the three gunas of nature as the basis for categorizing the PurÄÅ†as, depending on such statements as, “knowledge is born of sattva-guna” [GÄªTÄ€ 14.17]1 and “sattva-guna leads to realization of the Absolute Truth” [SB 1.2.24], we must conclude that the Puranas and other lit- erature in sattva-guna are more authentic sources of knowledge of the Absolute Truth. 1 sattvÃ¤t sanjayate jÃ±Änam 2 sattvam yad brahma-darÅ›anam 112 18 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Fulfills the Criteria of Authority in the Matter of Ultimate Truth 18.2 à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¯ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µ- à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¤²à¥‹- à¤•à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¥‡à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤ à¥¤ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤šà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤—à¥‚à¤¢à¤¾- à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤¾à¤šà¤•à¥à¤·à¥€à¤¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¤à¤°à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ ? But even then, how can we reconcile the different inconclusive views put forward regarding the Absolute Truth? Someone may propose study of Vedanta-sutra as the solution, claiming that Bhagavan Vyasadeva compiled Vedanta-sutra to present the deci- sive conclusion of both the Vedas and the PurÄnas concerning the Absolute Truth. But then the followers of sages who wrote other sutras may not concur. Moreover, since the aphorisms of Vedanta are terse and extremely esoteric, and since they are also subject to varying interpretations, a contrary conclusion of the sutras is always likely to be expressed. What, then, can resolve disputes concerning the meaning of Vedanta-sÃ¼tra? 18.3 à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ - à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤®à¤ªà¥Œà¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾- à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤œà¥€à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤­à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤­à¥à¤µà¤¿ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤šà¤°à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤š à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤šà¤•à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¦à¤­à¤¿à¤®à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ à¥¥ [Jiva GosvÄmÄ« employs a literary device here of introducing an apparent objective witness, who responds to the question as fol- lows.] “This problem could be solved if there were one scrip- ture that had the characteristics of a Purana, that was without human origin, that presented the essence of all the Vedas, Iti- hÄsas, and PurÄnas, that was based on VedÄnta sÅ«tra, and that was available on earth in its complete form.” [To this Jiva responds : ] â€œMy dear sir, what you have said is an accurate statement of truth, and the specific criteria men- tioned by you particularly brings to mind our revered Åšrimad 113 II PramÄÅ†a BhÄgavatam, the emperor of all pramÄnas [because it fulfills the said criteria].” Commentary MATSYA PURANA, CHAPTER 53, specifies the number of verses in each PurÄÅ†a and describes the benefits of donating each of the PurÄÅ†as on special days. In that same chapter SÃ¼ta GosvÄmi speaks two and a half verses containing a formula for dividing the PurÄnas into three classes, according to which one of the three gunas of pri- mordial nature they predominantly embody. These three classes of Purana glorify various deities, and commentators often try to estab- lish their own favorite among these deities as supreme, arguing on the basis of logic and apparently conclusive scriptural references. One consequence of this partiality is that commentators tend to denigrate PurÄÅ†as belonging to a category different from their own: Proponents of tamasika Puranas tend to reject the authority of the rajasika and sattvika PurÄÅ†as, and proponents of rajasika and sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as likewise reject the Puranas outside their group. But there cannot actually be several Absolute Truths; therefore, the question of which Puranic deity is the one Supreme Truth remains to be settled. For the unbiased seeker of truth, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi demon- strates how to resolve the matter. He explains that the perspec- tive disclosed through the guna of luminosity and perpetual being (sattva) is clearly superior to that presented through the gunas of conditional becoming (rajas) and ignorance (tamas), as ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a confirms in Bhagavad GitÄ: From the guna of perpetual being (sattva), real knowledge develops; from the guna of conditional becoming (rajas) only greed develops; and from the guna of material stasis (tamas) develop negligence, delusion, and ignorance. (GITA 14.17)3 sattvÃ¤t saÃ±jÄyate jÃ±Änam rajaso lobha eva ca pramada-mohau tamaso bhavato jÃ±Änam eva ca 114 18 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Fulfills the Criteria of Authority in the Matter of Ultimate Truth Srimad Bhagavatam also states: Conditional becoming is superior to stasis, but perpetual being is better yet, because it can lead to direct unmediated vision of the Absolute Truth. (SB 1.2.24) This verse follows a passage (SB 1.2.23) in which SÅ«ta GosvÄmÄ« is explaining which form of worship yields the ultimate good. His opinion is that one can achieve the ultimate good only by worship- ing ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, the complete personification of unadulterated being (viÅ›uddha-sattva). The citation from Matsya Purana in the previous anuccheda states that the sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as glorify Lord Hari, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. By con- trast, the rajasika and tamasika PurÄÅ†as recommend worship of other deities. Such worship embodies the perspectives of the lower gunas of nature, and hence is not by its inherent nature directed toward immediate realization of the Absolute Truth. Thus, one can tell which guna a Purana embodies by taking note of the deity it recommends for worship. Another way to tell is by how it commences. In the sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as, a questioner will approach a learned speaker and inquire from him about the Abso- lute Truth. The questioner may ask the speaker to elaborate on the nature of Ultimate Reality, the supreme path of transcendence for all, the ultimate benefit a human being can aspire for, how one should prepare for death, or similar topics. Such questions then allow the speaker of the Purana full freedom to explain these topics. The speaker who is self-realized, free from all gross and subtle mate- rial desires, and concerned only with the welfare of the inquirer and those who will hear the discourse either in the present or in the future, then replies with answers that are specific and unambigu- ous, leaving no room for misinterpretation or confusion. Examples of such sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as include Padma Purana, ViÅŸÅ†u Purana, and, most prominently, Bhagavata Purana, or Srimad Bhagavatam. In the rajasika and tÄmasika PurÄÅ†as, however, the questioners inquire about limited topics related to conditional becoming and 4 tamasas tu rajas tasmat sattvam yad brahma-darÅ›anam 11511 PramÄÅ†a material stasis, which do not address the ultimate concern of life, related to eternal or timeless being. For example, in Linga Purana, the sages at Naimiá¹£Äranya ask SÅ«ta GosvÄmÄ« to narrate the glories of Linga, Lord Siva. Although SÃ¼ta GosvÄmi has fully realized the Absolute Truth and is perfectly competent to explain it, the ques- tions here restrict him to speaking on the particular topic of Linga. He is not requested to explain the deeper meaning of life. Since all rajasika and tÄmasika PurÄÅ†as share this inherent shortcoming, they cannot be reliable sources of knowledge about the essential topics of sambandha, abhidheya, and prayojana. The Puranas were arranged according to the different gunas in correspondence with the various desires and psychological dispo- sitions of conditioned human beings. Nevertheless, every PurÄÅ†a somewhere contains glorification of Sri Hari, the Absolute Truth. ÅšrÄ«la VedavyÄsa included this glorification so that, while hearing or reading the tamasika and rajasika PurÄÅ†as, even persons situated in the lower material gunas could be offered the possibility of hav- ing their consciousness turned toward its ultimate complete source, Bhagavan. Someone might object that the statement cited above concern- ing the classification of the Puranas according to the gunas does not itself come from a sÃ¤ttvika Purana and so should not be taken as authoritative. We reply that this classification is supported by numerous other statements as well, including some from sÃ¤ttvika scriptures such as Padma Purana, which we have already cited in the previous anuccheda. Nor is it true that the PurÄÅ†as in the lower gunas contain no valid knowledge at all; rather, they provide some insight into Absolute Reality, what to speak of the insights they give into lesser topics. In addition, no statement in the Vedic liter- ature specifically contradicts the verses cited here classifying the PurÄÅ†as according to the gunas of nature, and so we are left with no compelling reason to doubt the authenticity of this classification. From this analysis we can conclude that in our quest for the ulti- mate Å›abda-pramÄÅ†a we need to consider only the sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as. As Padma PurÄÅ†a states, sÄttvikÄ moká¹£a-dÄá¸¥ proktÄá¸¥: “The PurÄÅ†as that embody the guna of perpetual being (sattva) are said to directly 116 18 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Fulfills the Criteria of Authority in the Matter of Ultimate Truth award liberation.” But even these sÃ¤ttvika Puranas have been under- stood in many different ways by great thinkers. Some interpreters have found that they glorify the path of yoga as ultimate, others have concluded that they recommend bhakti as the highest path, and yet others have found that they promote the path of jÃ±ana (knowledge) as supreme. For this reason ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi proposes the Vedanta-sutra as a possible basis of reconciliation. As stated earlier, there are four Vedas divided into four parts, the Upanisads being the fourth of these. The Upanisads encompass the essential meaning of the Vedas. They are considered as the cream of the Vedas and are thus called Vedanta. The Upanisads, however, also apparently contain contra- dictions. To solve this problem, Vyasadeva wrote the Vedanta-sutra, also called the Brahma-sutra, in which he incorporates the essential understanding of the Vedas and the principal Upanisads. But we must also consider that the dedicated followers of other sages who wrote philosophical sutras, such as Gautama and PataÃ±- jali, might not accept the conclusions of Vedanta-sutra. Even if the followers of other philosophers could be somehow convinced to enlarge their stance by logical proof of the greater authority of Vedanta-sutra, the situation is still problematic: The sutras of Vedanta are terse and esoteric, and acÄryas of various persuasions have commented on them in such a way that it is difficult to decide whose opinion agrees with that of Åšrila Vedavyasa, the author. The main contenders are the adherents of Advaitavada and the Vaiá¹£á¹‡avas. The debate between these two groups has continued for more than a thousand years. For the seeker who has come this far along the way but finds him- self sinking in the swampy confusion created by the various scrip- tures and their myriad commentators, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« finally points out the high ground of Srimad Bhagavatam. The Bhagava- tam has the ten characteristics of a major Purana (discussed in Anuccheda 56); it is transhuman in nature (apauruÅŸeya); it is the natural commentary on the Vedanta-sÃ¼tra and thus constitutes the purport of all the Vedas, ItihÄsas, and PurÄÅ†as; it is available in its entirety; it is respected by all Vaiá¹£á¹‡ava ÄcÄryas and many others 117 II Pramana including the AdvaitavÄdÄ«s; it is the most popular of the PurÄÅ†as; it has an intact tradition of Vaisnava commentaries; and it is the culmination of Åšrila Vedavyasa’s literary output, being composed in His maturity. By establishing Åšrimad Bhagavatam as the last word among Vedic scriptures, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi fulfills the will of ÅšrÄ« Caitanya Maha- prabhu, who accepted the Bhagavatam as the “spotless Purana,” the supremely authoritative text. In the next anuccheda, Jiva GosvÄmi explains that ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam has not been composed by a mortal and that it is the natural commentary on the Vedanta-sutra. 118 The Characteristics of ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam That Establish Its Epistemological Validity Anucchedas 19-26 In the previous anucchedas, Srimad Bhagavatam has been shown to be Vedic in origin, meaning that it is of the same transhuman, and thus transconceptual, nature. Furthermore, it has been shown to embody the essence of the Vedas, containing their innermost mean- ing. As such, it is to be approached in the same manner as the Vedas, that is, as sabda. As discussed already in the previous division on epistemology, this implies the activation of a transphenomenal mode of knowing in consciousness, in which Reality discloses itself through its self-revealing power of sound. In this case, because ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam embodies not only Reality devoid of phenome- nal distinction, but Reality complete with its own interior plenum, the transcendental knowing that it self-reveals is identical with this complete Reality, known as Bhagavan. The anucchedas in this division delineate a few of the primary characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam that further specify its episte- mological validity. But again, this is not merely to convince us of the BhÄgavata’s authority as a discursive reference text about Real- ity. The intent, rather, is to actualize the possibility of the direct knowing of that Reality. So the primary characteristics enumer- ated, such as “Åšrimad Bhagavatam is the Natural Commentary on Vedanta-sutra and the Essence of Gayatri,” function more as sÅ«tras or keys that turn or unlock consciousness to disclose their own meaning, identical with the Reality they signify. 119 Anuccheda 19 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is the Natural Commentary on Vedanta-sutra and the Essence of Gayatri 19.1 à¥§à¥¯ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ INDEED, Lord Vyasa was not satisfied even after compiling all the Puranas and the Vedanta-sutra. He therefore brought forth Srimad Bhagavatam, which was revealed to Him in trance, as the natural commentary on His own sutras. In Srimad Bhaga- vatam we find the consistent reconciliation of all scriptures, as understood from the fact that the Bhagavatam’s truth revelation unfolds directly from the Gayatri mantra, the embodiment of the essential meaning of all the Vedas. 19.2 à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‡ (à¥«à¥©à¥§à¥¨à¥¦-à¥¨à¥¨ ) - This characteristic of Srimad Bhagavatam is described in Matsya PurÄna: à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤µà¤§à¥‹à¤ªà¥‡à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥­ à¥¥ 121 II PramÄÅ†a à¤²à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤š à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤®à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥Œà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥® à¥¥ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥ªà¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ That Purana is known as Åšrimad Bhagavatam which delineates the path of Ultimate Truth (dharma-vistara) with reference to the Gayatri mantra and tells of the killing of the demon Vá¹›tra. Whoever writes out a copy of Åšrimad Bhagavatam, places it on a golden lion-throne, and presents it to a worthy person on the full-moon day of the month of Bhadra (August-September) will attain the supreme destination. This PurÃ¤na has eighteen thousand verses. (MP 53.20-22)1 19.3 à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥‚à¤šà¤•à¤¤à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤§à¥€à¤®à¤¹à¤¿à¤ªà¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤²à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤š â€œà¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ " ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥§) “à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¦à¤¾â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‡à¤°à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤° à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ªà¤°à¤ƒ à¥¤ â€œà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤•à¥ˆà¤¤à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¨ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸ à¤š à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£ à¤à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤­à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ Here the word gayatri specifically indicates the meaning of the Gayatri mantra, which is connected to the word dhimahi. Dhimahi is a signifier of Gayatri, implying without exception the complete mantra. Because Gayatri is the origin of all Vedic mantras, it would have been improper to utter it directly. The first verse of Srimad Bhagavatam (SB 1.1.1) alludes to the meaning of Gayatri by the phrases janmady asya yataá¸¥ (“by Him this uni- verse is created, maintained, and destroyed”) and tene brahma há¹›da (“He revealed the Vedic truth [to Lord Brahma] within the heart”). These phrases express the same meaning as Gayatri by describing Bhagavan as the basis of all the universes and as He who inspires everyone’s wisdom faculty. 1 yatrÃ¤dhiká¹›tya gayatrim varnyate dharma-vistaraá¸¥ vá¹›trasura-vadhopetam tad-bhagavatam iÅŸyate likhitva tac ca yo dadyad dhema-simha-samanvitam praustha-padyam paurá¹‡amasyam sa yati paramam gatim aá¹£á¹­Ädasa-sahasrani puranam tat prakirtitam 122 19 Åšrimad Bhagavatam Is the Natural Commentary on Vedanta-sÅ«tra and the Essence of Gayatri The word dharma in the compound dharma-vistara [from the same Matsya Purana verse] refers to the path of Ultimate Truth (parama-dharma), as expressed in the Bhagavatam by the words dharmaá¸¥ projjhita-kaitavo’tra paramah (SB 1.1.2): “The Bhagava- tam propounds the way of Ultimate Truth, devoid of all forms of deceit and compromise.“2 And, as will become clear in the upcoming anucchedas, this dharma is indeed characterized by meditation on the Supreme Personal Absolute, Bhagavan. Commentary SRIMAD BHAGAVATAM CONTAINS THE STORY of its own appearance as the crowning achievement of Åšrila Vyasadeva’s literary efforts. First, Åšrila Vyasadeva arranged the four Vedas, and then He com- posed the great epic Mahabharata for the benefit of women, sudras, and others who are ineligible to study the Vedas, because they do not undergo the sacred thread ceremony (upanayana-saá¹skÄra), which is considered a prerequisite for the study of the Veda. Next, He compiled the Puranas, the natural commentaries on the Vedas, and then He provided the essence of the Vedas and PurÄÅ†as in the Vedanta-sutra. But even after all this literary output, VedavyÄsa felt discontented, although He did not know why. Then His spiritual teacher, Narada Muni, approached Him and identified what was still lacking in His exposition of Ultimate Truth: You have composed a great and extraordinary work, MahÄbhÄ- rata, which elaborately explains the various goals of life. Thus, the investigation of Immanent Truth undertaken by you has been fully realized. (SB 1.5.3)3 You have also inquired into and realized the eternal transcendent Absolute, Brahman. Yet, in spite of all this, O illustrious One, you dharmaá¸¥ projjhita-kaitavo’tra paramaá¸¥ jijnÃ¤sitam susampannam api te mahad adbhutam ká¹›tavan bharatam yas tvam sarvartha-paribá¹›mhitam 123 II PramÄá¹‡a lament your condition as if your efforts have been in vain. (SB 1.5.4)* O best of sages, you have not elaborated the glories of the Sup- reme Personal Absolute, Vasudeva, to the same extent as you have repeatedly described the four human goals beginning with dharma. (SB 1.5.9)5 On Narada Muni’s instruction, Åšrila Vyasa ascended the path of meditation, and while in the state of supracognitive trance, ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam was revealed to Him. Thus, it is clear that Srimad BhÄga- vatam, which provided final solace to Vyasadeva, is knowledge descended from the transcendental realm. In upcoming anucche- das, ÅšrÄ« Jiva will show that it is also the natural commentary on Vedanta-sutra. Various PurÄnas mention the relationship between ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam and the Gayatri mantra. Gayatri is considered the essence of the Vedas and is supposed to be recited at dawn, noon, and dusk by every twice-born person (brÄhmaá¹‡a, ká¹£atriya, or vaisya). According to ÅšrÄ«dhara Svami in BhÄvÄrtha-dipika, ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam begins with the Gayatri mantra. Commenting on the first verse of the Bhagavatam, he writes: That the Gayatri phrase indicated by the word dhimahi begins this Purana, shows that this work embodies the revealed knowledge of the Absolute (brahma-vidya), known as Gayatri. (BhÄvÄrtha- dipika 1.1.1) Because Åšrimad Bhagavatam is based on Gayatri, the cream of the Vedas, it delineates the path of Ultimate Truth. The Bhagavatam thus calls itself “the ripened fruit of the wish-fulfilling tree of the Vedas” (nigama-kalpa-taror galitam phalam, SB 1.1.3). 5 The recitation of Gayatri and other Vedic mantras is governed by strict rules regarding the person, time, place, and purification jijÃ±Äsitam adhitam ca yat tad-brahma sanatanam athÄpi Å›ocasyÄtmÄnam aká¹›tÄrtha iva prabho yatha dharmadayas cartha muni-varyÄnukÄ«rtitÄá¸¥ na tatha vasudevasya mahima hy anuvarnitaá¸¥ âš« dhimahiti gayatryÃ¤ prarambhena ca gayatry-akhya-brahma-vidya-rupam etat puranam iti darsitam. 124 19 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Natural Commentary on Vedanta-sÅ«tra and the Essence of Gayatri rites incumbent on the chanter, but such restrictions do not apply to Srimad Bhagavatam. Since anyone may read the BhÄgavatam, strictly speaking it would be improper for the Gayatri mantra to appear there in its original form. Gayatri is considered the most important among the Vedic mantras, but only the twice-born are allowed to chant them. That is why ÅšrÄ«la Vyasadeva enfolded the form and idea of Gayatri in the Bhagavatam without quoting the actual words of the mantra. Only one word from Gayatri, dhimahi, has been kept to indicate his intention because it is a compulsory word in the mantra and carries its essence. Another reason Vyasa did not write the original Gayatri in Srimad Bhagavatam is that doing so would have invited misinter- pretation. Various schools of thought have explained Gayatri dif- ferently as a meditation on unqualified Brahman, on the sun, on the fire god, on Lord Siva, and so forth. Only rarely is it understood as a meditation on the Supreme Personal Absolute, Vasudeva. But in Srimad Bhagavatam, ÅšrÄ«la Vyasadeva’s own commentary on the Vedanta-sutra, Vyasadeva delivers the complete and unambiguous meaning of Gayatri in the opening verse. He reveals that Gayatri is a meditation on the original Supreme Person, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, and His eternal consort, ÅšrÄ« RÄdhikÄ. This meditation is indeed the highest dharma. In Anuccheda 105 of Sri Paramatma Sandarbha, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi will explain the Gayatri mantra in detail, and in Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a Sandarbha, he will give a thorough analysis of the Bhagavatam’s first verse as a meditation on ÅšrÄ« ÅšrÄ« Radha Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. Here, in the next anuccheda of Tattva Sandarbha, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi further introduces Åšrimad Bhagavatam, describing its dis- tinguishing features and supporting his statements with scriptural references. 125Anuccheda 20 The Characteristics of ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam 20.1 1 à¥¨à¥¦ à¥¤ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¤š “à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¥ " ( à¥­à¥¤à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥¤à¥ªà¥¦-à¥ªà¥¨ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ IN SKANDA PURANA we find a description of Srimad Bhagavatam similar to the one in Matsya Purana:1 à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥à¤°à¥à¤¨à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤µà¤‚ à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥‡ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤š à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤²à¤¿à¤–à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤š à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤®à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥Œà¤°à¥à¤£à¤®à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥Œà¤·à¥à¤ à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥§ à¥¥ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¨ à¥¥ The Purana known as Åšrimad Bhagavatam recounts the deeds of humans and devas in the Sarasvata-kalpa, explains the way of Supreme Truth in terms of Gayatri, and narrates the slay- ing of Vá¹›trÃ¤sura. It has eighteen thousand verses. Whoever writes out a copy of the Bhagavatam, places it on a golden lion- throne, and presents it to a worthy person on the full-moon day of the month of Bhadra, will attain the supreme destination. (Prabhasa-khanda 7.1.2.40-42)2 MP 53.20-22 quoted in Anuccheda 19.2. sarasvatasya kalpasya madhye ye syur naramarÄá¸¥ tad-vrttantodbhavam loke tac ca bhagavatam smá¹›tam likhitva tac ca yo dadyad dhema-simha-samanvitam paurá¹‡amÃ¤syÃ¤á¹ praustha-padyam sa yati paramam gatim aÅŸá¹­Ädasa-sahasrani puranaá¹ tat prakirtitam Alternate reading of Skanda Purana 7.1.2.40: sarasvatasya kalpasya madhye Å›rÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« [ BhÄvÄrtha-dÄ«pikÄ 1.1.1], confirms the epistemological validity of Srimad Bhagavatam thus: à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¤¾à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤§à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥«à¥© à¥¥ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤š à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥ˆ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥ª à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ The Purana known as Srimad Bhagavatam contains eighteen thousand verses divided into twelve cantos, begins with Gaya- trÄ«, describes the transcendental knowledge (brahma-vidyÄ) imparted by HayagrÄ«va, and narrates the slaying of Vá¹›trasura. 20.3 à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° â€œà¤¹à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾” à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤§à¤¸à¤¾à¤¹à¤šà¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤µà¤°à¥à¤®à¥ˆà¤µà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¹à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾- à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¤¾ à¤¦à¤§à¥€à¤šà¤¿à¤°à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ The transcendental knowledge (brahma-vidya) imparted by Hayagriva here refers to the â€œArmor of NÄrÄyana” (nÄrÄyana- 3 ÅšrÄ« Jiva GosvÄmi simply says that these verses are found in another Purana. We have traced them to Agni PurÄna (272.6 - 7 ). In the latter source, however, the verses do not appear in complete form nor in the same order as that found in Skanda PurÄna.

  • grantho’stadaÅ›a sahasro dvÄdaÅ›a-skandha-sammitah hayagriva brahma-vidyÄ yatra vrtra-vadhas tatha gayatryÄƒ ca samarambhas tad vai bhagavatam viduá¸¥ 127 II PramÄÅ†a varma), since it is narrated in the same context as the killing of Vá¹›tra. The name haya-grÄ«va here refers to Dadhici, the sage with a horse’s head. He taught the knowledge of Brahman known as nÄrÄyaá¹‡a-varma. His accepting a horse’s head and receiving the fitting name AÅ›vaÅ›ira are mentioned in the Sixth Canto of Åšrimad BhÄgavatam, where these words are spoken: “he who has the name AÅ›vaÅ›irÄ” […]. The NÄrÄyaá¹‡a-varma is in fact a teach- ing regarding the Absolute (brahma-vidya), as indicated in the following statement: à¤à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¥‹à¤µà¤¾à¤š à¤¦à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤™à¤¾à¤¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥«à¥« à¥¥ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ “Upon hearing this and feeling honored, Dadhici, anxious not to break his promise, instructed the twin AÅ›vini-kumÄras in the knowledge of the Pravargya sacrifice and brahma-vidya.” This verse is cited from Sridhara Svami’s commentary on the above text of the Bhagavatam (6.9.52). 20.4 à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¥€à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤š à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤…à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤°à¥€à¤·à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¥Œà¤¤à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶à¥à¤¨à¤ƒ - Since Srimad Bhagavatam is the beloved of Bhagavan and is cease- lessly longed for by His devotees, it is the scripture of supreme transcendence (parama-sÃ¤ttvika). The Bhagavatam’s dearness to Bhagavan and His devotees is indicated in Padma Purana, in Gautama Rá¹£i’s question to MahÄrÄja AmbarÄ«á¹£a: The entire chapter (SB 6.8) is devoted to this topic. Varma means armor or a protective shield. It is synonymous with the word kavaca. Specific mantras dedicated to a particular deity that are intended as protective spells are generally given these names. They are meant to be recited at times of danger or carried on the body to ward off negative energies. âš«etac chrutva tathovaca dadhyan atharvanas tayoá¸¥ pravargyam brahma-vidyam ca sat-ká¹›to’satya-sankitaá¸¥ 128 20 The Characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤ à¤¸à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤šà¤°à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤š à¤­à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¬ à¥¥ O lord of the earth, do you recite Bhagavata PurÄá¹‡a before the Deity of Lord Hari, especially the history of the king of the demons, [the great devotee] Prahlada MahÄrÄja? (Uttara- khanda 22.115)” à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤à¥à¤œà¥à¤²à¥€à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ - Again, in the section of Padma Purana glorifying the vow of VaÃ±juli MahÄ-dvÄdaÅ›Ä«, Gautama further instructs AmbarÄ«á¹£a: à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥Œ à¤¤à¥ à¤œà¤¾à¤—à¤°à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¥€ à¤•à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥«à¥­ à¥¥ à¤—à¥€à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤ à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤·à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥® à¥¥ One should keep vigil throughout that ceremonial night, lending full oral reception to the scriptural narrations of ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u and His devotees - especially, Bhagavad Gita, the thousand names of ÅšrÄ« ViÅŸÅ†u, and the Purana narrated by Sukadeva [ÅšrÄ«mad Bhaga- vatam]. One should recite these with care and attention for they bring delight to ÅšrÄ« Haris 20.5 à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°- [And the Bhagavatam’s being a scripture that embodies and hence awards supreme transcendence (parama-sÃ¤ttvika), trans- porting one beyond material existence, is indicated in the next two references.] Elsewhere in Padma Purana we find this 2 statement: puranam tvam bhagavatam paá¹­hase purato hareh caritam daitya-rajasya prahladasya ca bhÃ¼pate ratrau tu jÄgaraá¸¥ karyaá¸¥ Å›rotavyÃ¤ vaiá¹£á¹‡avi kathÄ gitanam asahasram ca puranam suka-bhÄá¹£itam pathitavyaá¹ prayatnena hareá¸¥ santoá¹£a-karaá¹‡am This verse is not found in the printed version of Padma Purana. 129 11 Pramana à¤…à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤°à¥€à¤· à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥ƒà¤£à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤ à¤¸à¥à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤–à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¯à¤¦à¥€à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¸à¤¿ à¤­à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥«à¥¯ à¥¥ O AmbarÄ«È™a, if you wish to bring to a close your material exis- tence, then every day you should hear the Bhagavatam that was narrated by Sukadeva and let it be uttered too from your very own mouth. à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡-

Finally, we find the following statement in the Prahlada-samhitÄƒ of Skanda Purana, in the section describing the glories of DvÄrakÃ¤: à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¤ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤œà¤¾à¤—à¤°à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥à¤²à¤µà¥ƒà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ A person who keeps vigil [on the night of Ekadasi] and recites Srimad Bhagavatam with devotion before the Deity of Sri Hari is transported to the Lord’s abode along with his entire family.” Commentary IN THIS ANUCCHEDA, JÄ«va GosvÄmÄ« gives special attention to iden- tifying Åšrimad Bhagavatam. He does this because some scholars of his time held that Devi Bhagavatam, rather than Srimad Bhagava- tam, was actually the Bhagavatam glorified in the PurÄÅ†as. Like Åšrimad Bhagavatam, Devi BhÄgavatam is a PurÄÅ†a with twelve can- tos, eighteen thousand verses, and an account of Vá¹›trÃ¤sura’s death, although its account of how Vá¹›tra was killed differs from the one in Åšrimad Bhagavatam. Also, when some traditional scholars read in the Puranas that on the full-moon day of the month of Bhadra one should donate the Bhagavatam mounted on a golden lion (hema- simha), they take this to mean Devi Bhagavatam. This seems quite “ambariÅŸa suka-proktam nityam bhÄgavatam Å›á¹›á¹‡u pathasva sva-mukhenaiva yadicchasi bhava-ká¹£ayam Srimad-bhagavatam bhaktyÃ¤ paá¹­hate hari-sannidhau jÃ¤gare tat-padam yÃ¤ti kula-vá¹›nda-samanvitaá¸¥ 130 20 The Characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam fitting, since Devi, or DurgÄ, rides on a lion. In the case of ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam, hema-simha is understood to mean “a golden lion- throne.” ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi solves the controversy by citing references that list distinctive features of Srimad Bhagavatam: It begins with the Gayatri mantra, it contains the hayagriva-brahma-vidya, the events it narrates happened in the Sarasvata-kalpa, and it was first spoken by ÅšrÄ« Sukadeva GosvÃ¤mi to Pariká¹£it MahÄrÄja. JÄ«va GosvÄmÄ« further supports his opinion by quoting from the BhÄvÄrtha-dipikÄ, Sridhara SvÄmi’s commentary on Srimad Bhagavatam. Devi BhÄgavatam opens with a statement that appears to be based on Gayatri: om sarva-caitanya-rupÄm tÄm ÄdyÄá¹ vidyaá¹ ca dhimahi, buddhim ya naá¸¥ pracodayat. There are two reasons this statement should not be equated with Gayatri: First, nothing in it corresponds to the words savituá¸¥, varenyam, and bhargas from Gayatri, whereas such a correspondence can be shown in SB 1.1.1. Second, this statement is a meditation on Devi, but as ÅšrÄ« JÄ«va will show in the next anuccheda, the object of meditation in Gayatri is the Supreme Personal Absolute, ÅšrÄ« Viá¹£á¹‡u. Like Srimad Bhagavatam, Devi Bhagavatam also narrates the killing of Vá¹›trasura, but in that account, Indra kills Vá¹›tra with ocean foam empowered by Devi. Vá¹›trÃ¤sura performed severe pen- ances for hundreds of years to please Lord Brahma. When BrahmÄ appeared before him and offered a boon, Vá¹›tra asked to not be slain by any weapon made of iron or wood, dry or wet. After Lord Brahma granted this boon, Vá¹›tra attacked Indra and defeated him. Indra subsequently took help from ÅšrÄ« ViÅŸÅ†u, who entered Indra’s thunderbolt and advised him to take the help of Devi and make a truce with Vá¹›tra. Indra then apparently befriended Vá¹›trÄsura. But one day at dusk Indra surprised Vá¹›trasura on a beach and slew him with his thunderbolt, which is not a weapon of iron or wood, and was covered with foam, which is neither wet nor dry. Devi Bhagavatam also makes no mention of the hayagriva- brahma-vidya, i.e., the nÄrÄyaá¹‡a-varma. For all these reasons it is clear that the Bhagavatam referred to in the verse cited by Åšridhara SvÄmÄ« is not Devi Bhagavatam. 131 II PramÄÅ†a HemÄdrÄ«, BallÄlasena, GovindÄnanda, Raghunandana, Gopala Bhaá¹­á¹­a GosvÄmi, and Sanatana GosvÄmÄ« have each written note- worthy dharma-Å›Ã¤stras, or books and essays on religious duties, in which they quote frequently from Srimad Bhagavatam but never from Devi BhÄgavatam. BallÃ¤lasena states in Dana-sÃ¤gara that only a few verses of the Bhagavatam specifically recommend acts of char- ity. In contrast, the entire thirtieth chapter of Devi BhÄgavatam’s Ninth Canto deals exclusively with the glories of various kinds of charitable giving. In addition, with the exceptions of RÄmÄnujÄcÄ- rya and Nilakaá¹‡á¹­hÄcÄrya, all the great saintly commentators on prasthana-trayÄ« either wrote about Srimad Bhagavatam directly or at least cited it as a standard reference in their books. By contrast, nei- ther Sankara, MadhvacÄrya, VallabhacÄrya, ÅšrÄ« Caitanyadeva, nor any other notable acarya has ever cited Devi Bhagavatam to support or prove any of their important statements. Chapter 96 of the first part of Naradiya PurÄÅ†a lists the topics of all twelve cantos of the Bhagavatam in order. This list fits ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam, not Devi Bhagavatam. Padma Purana states: Among all the PurÄnas, Srimad Bhagavatam is ultimate. In every line great sages sing the glories of ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a in various ways. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 193.3)” All this leaves no doubt that the Bhagavatam mentioned in the quoted Puranic verses is Åšrimad Bhagavatam. ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam and other PurÄÅ†as mention an asura named HayagrÄ«va, and there is also an avatara of ÅšrÄ« Visnu called Hayagriva, who had a horse’s head. But because the Hayagriva mentioned in this section of Tattva Sandarbha is connected with the slaying of the asura Vá¹›tra, ÅšrÄ«la JÄ«va GosvÄmÄ« has identified him as the sage Dadhici. As recounted in the Sixth Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, after Vá¹›tra had conquered the devas, they approached ÅšrÄ« Viá¹£á¹‡u for help. The Lord advised the chief of the devas, Indra, to approach Dadhici and ask him for “purÃ¢neÈ™u tu sarveÅŸu Å›rimad-bhagavatam param yatra prati-padam ká¹›á¹£á¹‡o giyate bahudharÅŸibhiá¸¥ 132 20 The Characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam his body, which had been rendered adamantine by vows, penances, and knowledge of Brahman. The Lord told Indra to fashion from Dadhici’s bones a thunderbolt strong enough to kill Vá¹›trÄsura. Dadhici had previously taught knowledge of Brahman to the AÅ›vini-kumÄra twins, although Indra had earlier forbidden him to teach them transcendental knowledge on the grounds that their profession as physicians disqualified them. Indra had threatened to behead Dadhici if he disobeyed, but Dadhici had already promised to teach the twins. The AÅ›vini-kumÄras solved Dadhici’s dilemma surgically: They severed his head and grafted a horse’s head in its place, knowing that Indra would eventually cut off that head, after which they could restore the original one. Dadhici then instructed them straight from the horse’s mouth. Because of this, Dadhici also became known as Hayagriva (horse-necked) or AÅ›vaÅ›ira (horse- headed), and the transcendental knowledge he imparted became famous as the hayagrÄ«va-brahma-vidya. As anticipated, Indra did indeed sever Dadhici’s horse head, and the AÅ›vini-kumÄras restored the original one. Then, on the request of the devas, Dadhici offered his body to Indra, who used his bones to fashion the thunderbolt with which he was to kill Vá¹›trÄsura. Dadhici taught the same knowledge he had given to the AÅ›vini- kumÄras to Tvaá¹£á¹­Ä, who in turn taught it to his son ViÅ›varupa. ViÅ›varupa then taught it to Lord Indra as the “NÄrÄyaá¹‡a Armor,” which was instrumental in helping him defeat Vá¹›trÃ¤sura. Thus, the Hayagriva referred to here is Dadhici, and the brahma-vidya is the NÄrÄyaá¹‡a Armor. This is all described in the Sixth Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, along with the commentaries of the Vaisnava ÄcÄryas. Anuccheda 20.5 contains the term suka-prokta, or “narrated by ÅšrÄ« Suka.” From this we should not infer that all verses not spoken by Sukadeva GosvÄmi, such as the First Canto, are not part of Srimad Bhagavatam. The Bhagavatam Vyasa revealed was complete, includ- ing future events and future statements by SÅ«ta and Saunaka. Since Srimad Bhagavatam has been identified as having eighteen thou- sand verses and opening with a verse based on the Gayatri mantra, it must be that its first verse begins janmady asya yataá¸¥ and its last one ends with tam namami harim param. 133 II PramÄÅ†a Of the eighteen Puranas, six are meant for human beings predominantly influenced by the guna of inertia (tamas), six are for those influenced by the guna of conditional becoming (rajas), and six are for those influenced by the guna of perpetual being (sattva); but Srimad Bhagavatam occupies a place of honor even among the sÃ¤ttvika PurÄÅ†as. It is considered nondifferent from Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, the Supreme Personal Absolute, and therefore, it is parama-sÃ¤ttvika, a manifestation of supreme transcendental being without any tinge of the material gunas. ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam is pleasing to Bhagavan Hari (hareá¸¥ santoÈ™a- karaá¹‡am), the transcendental Lord, who cannot be pleased by any- thing material. It is relished by His devotees, who scoff at the bliss of liberation, not to speak of the pleasure derived from reading some- thing mundane. For this reason, the sage Gautama recommends reciting Åšrimad Bhagavatam on Ekadasi, which is also called Hari- vÃ¤sara, the day of Lord Hari. As Skanda Purana states: Srimad Bhagavatam and the Supreme Personal Absolute, Bhaga- vÃ¤n, are always exclusively of one inherent nature - that of eternal being, primordial consciousness, and transcendental bliss. (Skanda Purana, Visnu-khanda 6.4.3)12 Padma Purana confirms this: Without a doubt, this Srimad Bhagavatam is directly ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. (Uttara-khanda 198.30)13 That Srimad Bhagavatam is nondifferent from ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a is confirmed in the BhÄgavatam itself, where SÃ¼ta GosvÄmÄ« states that after Bhagavan’s disappearance, the Bhagavatam appeared as His representative to enlighten the ignorant people of Kaliyuga (SB 1.3.43). Padma Purana also confirms the oneness of the Bhaga- vatam and Bhagavan by comparing the various cantos with Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s limbs: 12 Srimad-bhagavatasyatha Å›rimad-bhagavataá¸¥ sada svarupam ekam evÄsti sac-cid-ananda-laká¹£aá¹‡am 13 Å›rimad-bhÄgavatakhyo’yam pratyaká¹£aá¸¥ ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a eva hi 134 20 The Characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam O King, the First and Second Cantos of the Bhagavatam are ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s feet, and the Third and Fourth Cantos are His thighs. The Fifth Canto is His navel, the Sixth Canto is His chest, and the Sev- enth and Eighth Cantos are His arms. The Ninth Canto is His throat, the Tenth His blooming lotus face, the Eleventh His forehead, and the Twelfth His head. I bow down to that Lord, the ocean of mercy, whose color is like that of a tamala tree and who appears in this world for the welfare of all. I worship Him as the bridge for crossing the unfathomable ocean of material existence. Åšrimad Bhagavatam has appeared as His very self14 Next, Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi points out that Srimad Bhagavatam is the natural commentary on the Vedanta-sutra and that it also elucidates the meaning of Mahabharata. padau yadÄ«yau prathama-dvitiyau tá¹›tiya-turyau kathitau yad-Ã¼rÃ¼ nabhis tatha paÃ±cama eva ÅŸaÅŸá¹­ho bhujÃ¤ntaram dor-yugalam tathanyau kanthas tu rajan navamo yadiyo mukharavindam daÅ›amam praphullam ekÃ¡daso yaÅ› ca lalaÈ›a-paá¹­á¹­am siro’pi yad dvadasa eva bhati namami devam karuna-nidhanam tamala-vará¹‡am suhitavatÄram apara-samsara-samudra-setur bhajamahe bhagavata-svarupam 135Anuccheda 21 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Establishes the Meaning of Mahabharata 21.1 à¥¨à¥§ à¥¤ à¤—à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¤š- GARUDA PURANA states:1 à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤£à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¤¤à¤¿à¤¶à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ || à¥¬à¥§ || à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¥‹à¤½à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤¸à¤¾à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥© à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ This [Bhagavatam] is the most complete of the Puranas. It embod- ies the essential meaning of Vedanta-sÃ¼tra; it establishes the meaning of Mahabharata; it is a commentary on Gayatri; it explains and expands the meaning of the Vedas; it is the Sama Veda of the PurÄÅ†as, and it is the direct utterance of the Sup- reme Absolute, ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan. It has twelve cantos, hundreds of chapters, and eighteen thousand verses; it is called ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam? Cited in Bhagavata-tÃ¤tparya 1.1.1 by Sri MadhvacÄrya. 2 pÃ¼rá¹‡aá¸¥ so’yam atisayaá¸¥ artho’yam brahma-sÃ¼trÄá¹‡Äá¹ bhÄratÃ¤rtha-vinirnayaá¸¥ gayatri-bhÄá¹£ya-rupo’sau vedartha-paribá¹›mhitaá¸¥ puraá¹‡ÄnÄá¹ sama-rupaá¸¥ sÄká¹£ad-bhagavatoditaá¸¥ dvadasa-skandha-yukto’yam sata-viccheda-samyutah grantho’stadasa-sahasraá¸¥ Å›rimad-bhÄgavatabhidhaá¸¥ 136 21.2 21 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Establishes the Meaning of Mahabharata à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤®à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤®à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥‚à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸à¥‚à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤®à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¶à¥à¤šà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥€à¤¨à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤µà¤•à¤ªà¥‹à¤²à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤—à¤¤à¤®à¥‡- à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤°à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤—à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ In the above statement, the phrase â€œ[Srimad BhÄgavatam]embod- ies the essential meaning of VedÃ¤nta-sutra” (brahma-sÅ«trÄá¹‡Äm arthaá¸¥) means that it is tantamount to being a natural commen- tary (akrtrima-bhÄsya) on VedÄnta-sutra. The BhÄgavatam first self-manifested in a subtle form to the awareness of ÅšrÄ« Vya- sadeva, who then summarized it in the form of Vedanta-sutra and later expanded it into Åšrimad Bhagavatam as we know it. Therefore, since Srimad Bhagavatam self-evidently embodies the natural commentary on Vedanta-sutra, all other recent commentaries, sprung from the fertile imagination of their authors, should be honored as authoritative only when they are in resonance with Srimad Bhagavatam. 21.3 à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ- Concerning the phrase bhÄratÄrtha-vinirnaya (Srimad Bhaga- vatam establishes the meaning of Mahabharata), the following verses may be cited: à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥ª à¥¥ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¤à¥à¤²à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤‹à¤·à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥« à¥¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¤¿à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¥ à¤š à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¬ à¥¥ Mahabharata is glorified because it contains the conclusions of all scriptures. Long ago, on the request of Åšrila Vyasa, Lord Brahma and the other devas gathered together with all the great 137 11 PramÄna sages and placed Mahabharata on one side of a scale and the entire Vedas on the other. As it turned out, MahÄbhÄrata out- weighed all of the Vedas. Because of its greatness (mahattva) and heaviness (bhÄra-vattva), it is called Maha-bhÄrata. (Adi- parva1.272-274) 3 à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¤ƒ à¥¤ It [the Bhagavata] is to be understood as that composition in which the meaning of Mahabharata, characterized in the latter verses, is made evident. 21.4 à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤·à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿ à¤œà¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤œà¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ (à¤®à¥¦ à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¥ à¥©à¥ªà¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥§-à¥§à¥ª ) -

Another reason why Srimad Bhagavatam establishes the mean- ing of Mahabharata is that the message of both culminates in ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan alone. That this is true of Mahabharata is evinced in the NÄrÄyaniya section of MahÄbhÄrata’s Moksa dharma portion, where Janamejaya says to ÅšrÄ«la Vyasadeva: à¤‡à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¤à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤†à¤®à¤¥à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¤à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¥‡à¤¨ à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥­ à¥¥ à¤¨à¤µ à¤¨à¥€à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¦à¤§à¥à¤¨à¥‹ à¤®à¤²à¤¯à¤¾à¤šà¥ à¤šà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤†à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤‚ à¤š à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤“à¤·à¤§à¤¿à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤½à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥® à¥¥ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥ à¤•à¤¥à¤¾à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤ªà¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¥‡ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¯à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¤•à¤¥à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥¬à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ O brahmana, abode of austerities, just as butter can be extracted from yogurt, sandalwood from the Malaya Mountains, the Upanisads from all the Vedas, and life-giving nectar from herbs, nirnayaá¸¥ sarva-sastrÄnÄá¹ bharatam parikirtitam bharataá¹ sarva-vedaÅ› ca tulÄm ÄropitÃ¤á¸¥ purÄ devair brahmadibhiá¸¥ sarvair rÅŸibhiÅ› ca samanvitaiá¸¥ vyÄsasyaivÃ¤jÃ±aya tatra tvatyaricyata bharatam mahattvad bhÄravattvÄc ca mahÄbhÄratam ucyate 138 1 21 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Establishes the Meaning of Mahabharata so by your churning the ocean of the highest knowledge with the rod of your discriminating wisdom, this NÄrÄyaá¹‡Ä«ya has been extracted from the hundred thousand verses of MahÄbhÃ¤- rata. This NÄrÄyaá¹‡Ä«ya, spoken by you, is the repository of the topics of Åšri NÄrÄyaá¹‡a, which are the nectar of immortality. (Moká¹£a-dharma 343.11-14)” Commentary ÅšRIMAD BHAGAVATAM is one of the eighteen Puranas, but ÅšrÄ«la Vya- sadeva wrote it after compiling the essence of the Vedas in Vedanta- sutra and after composing Mahabharata and the PurÄÅ†as. But if the eighteen PurÄÅ†as had already been compiled, does this make ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam the nineteenth? In Anuccheda 21.2, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi explains that this is not the case. ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam appeared first to Åšrila Vyasa in a concise form, as one of the eighteen PurÄÅ†as, and he composed Vedanta- sÃ¼tra on the basis of this first edition of the Bhagavatam. Later, when He was absorbed in supracognitive trance in pursuance of NÄrada Muni’s order, the expanded form of Srimad Bhagavatam was revealed to Him as the natural commentary on Vedanta-sutra. Srimad Bhagavatam and Vedanta-sutra share the same subject, the Absolute Truth, and they describe the same principles of samba- ndha (the whole-part existential relation between the Supreme Self and the individual self), abhidheya (the means of ultimate attain- ment), and prayojana (the completion stage of the means, uncon- ditional love of God). Many ÄcÄryas and scholars later wrote com- mentaries on Vedanta-sutra, but only those that accord with ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam - such as those of RÄmÄnujÄcÄrya, NimbÄrkÄcÄrya, MadhvÄcÄrya, VallabhÄcÄrya, and Baladeva VidyabhÅ«á¹£aá¹‡a â€” are authoritative. idam Å›atasahasrad dhi bhÄratÄkhyÄna vistarÄt amathya matimanthena jÃ±anodadhim anuttamam nava nitam yatha dadhno malayac candanam yatha aranyakaá¹ ca vedebhya oÅŸadhibhyo’má¹›tam yatha samuddhá¹›tam idam brahman kathamá¹›tam anuttamam tapo-nidhe tvayoktam hi nÄrÄyaá¹‡a-kathÄÅ›rayam 139 II PramÄÅ†a SÅ«ta GosvÄmi alludes to Vedavyasa’s composing two editions of Srimad Bhagavatam: The great sage Vyasadeva, after composing Srimad Bhagavatam and then revising it, taught it to His own son, the sage ÅšrÄ« Suka- deva GosvÄmi, who delighted in the state of utter non-attachment. (SB 1.7.8)5 Commenting on this verse, ÅšrÄ«la ViÅ›vanatha Cakravarti Thakura writes, “The word anukramya in this verse means that VedavyÄsa compiled a new (or revised) edition of the already existing ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam.” Anuccheda 21.3 relates how Mahabharata was once shown to be literally heavier than the Vedas. This came about because MahÄ- bharata, using simple narrations, elaborated upon and lucidly explained the concise and cryptic subject matter of the Vedas. Vyasadeva makes this point in Mahabharata: Lord Brahma, in this great work [Mahabharata] I have included the secret essence of all the Vedas and of all other scriptures as well. It explains in detail the Upanisads, the six corollaries, and the Vedas. (Mahabharata, Adi-parva 1.62)” Originally, Mahabharata had six million verses, but at present only one hundred thousand are available on earth. The rest can be found on planets of a higher dimension, where people have life spans and memories suitable for absorbing such large amounts of information. The distribution of Mahabharata’s verses is mentioned in Mahabharata itself: Then Åšrila Vyasadeva compiled another samhita [Mahabharata], containing six million verses. Of these, three million are present in the celestial planets, one and a half million on the planet of the forefathers, and one million four hundred thousand on the planet sa samhitam bhagavatim ká¹›tvÃ¤nukramya catmajam Sukam adhyapayam Ã¤sa nivá¹›tti-niratar muniá¸¥ atas tadaiva purva-nirmitasyaiva Å›ri-bhagavatasyanukramaÅ†am brahman veda-rahasyam ca yac canyat sthÃ¤pitam 7 maya sangopaniÅŸadam ca vedÃ¤nÄm vistara-kriya 140 21 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Establishes the Meaning of Mahabharata of the Gandharvas. The remaining one hundred thousand verses are available among human beings. (Mahabharata, Adi-parva 1.106- 107)8 Although abridged, the version of Mahabharata on this planet is the longest epic ever written. So, due to the profundity of its topics (mahattva) and its great weight (bhÃ¤ravattva), it is known as Mahabharata. The Mahabharata is more versatile than the Vedas, because the restrictions that apply to studying the Vedas are omitted in its case. Anyone may read and enjoy Mahabharata, regardless of social posi- tion or gender. However, only the Moká¹£a-dharma and a few other sections of Mahabharata directly glorify ÅšrÄ« NÄrÄyaá¹‡a as supreme. Other sections mainly deal with a mixture of topics, such as routine religious rituals, politics, and charity. By contrast, Åšrimad Bhagava- tam avoids all topics not related to the glories of the Supreme Lord. The entire Bhagavatam speaks only of this, and this exclusive focus is what makes it superior to Mahabharata. Thus, it has been said, “Srimad Bhagavatam establishes the meaning of Mahabharata.” In the next anuccheda, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« cites further proof that the BhÄgavatam is the essence of all Vedic literature and the topmost pramÄÅ†a. B sastim sata-sahasrani cakaranyam sa samhitam trimsac chata-sahasram ca deva-loke pratisthitam pitrye paÃ±cadasa proktam gandharveÅŸu caturdasa ekam sata-sahasram tu manuseÅŸu pratisthitam 141 Anuccheda 22 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature 22.1 à¥¨à¥¨ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤š à¤¤à¥ƒà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥©à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥§à¥¨ ) - SIMILARLY, the Third Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam confirms that Åšrimad Bhagavatam establishes the meaning of MahÄbhÄrata: à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¥à¤—à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤–à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¹ à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¥ƒà¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¨à¥ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤•à¤¥à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Your friend, the great sage Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a-dvaipayana Vyasa, composed his great work, Mahabharata, with the intention of describing the transcendental qualities of Åšri Bhagavan. In this work, he has drawn the attention of the mass of people to the descrip- tions of Åšri Hari by embedding them within the framework of mundane topics. ( SB 3.5.12 ) 1 22.2 à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤µ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤- à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° â€œà¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ [Now the explanation of the remaining part of the verse from Garuda PurÄna, cited in Anuccheda 21.1, is being given.] That munir vivaksur bhagavad-gunanam sakhapi te bharatam Ã¤ha ká¹›á¹£á¹‡aá¸¥ yasmin ná¹›á¹‡am gramya-sukhanuvadair matir grhitÃ¤ nu hareá¸¥ kathÄyÄm 142 22 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature Srimad Bhagavatam is a commentary on Gayatri is shown in Visnu-dharmottara Purana, which elaborately demonstrates, in its explanation of the Gayatri mantra ( Prathama - khanda 165 ), that the object of meditation in the Gayatri is ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan. We shall provide similar evidence that Srimad Bhagavatam is a com- mentary on Gayatri when we comment on the BhÄgavatam’s first verse? 22.3 “à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒâ€ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤£à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤šà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒâ€ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤¸ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤  à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ (à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤· à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥§à¥¬à¥¤à¥ªà¥¦-à¥ªà¥¨, à¥ªà¥ª, à¥©à¥© ) - The words vedÃ¤rtha-paribá¹›mhitaá¸¥ mean that Srimad Bhagavatam explains and expands the meaning of the Vedas, as indicated in MahÄbhÄrata (Adi-parva 1.267 ) : â€œOne should supplement the Vedas with the Itihasas and PurÄÅ†as.” The phrase purÄá¹‡ÄnÄá¹ sama-rupaá¸¥ (Srimad Bhagavatam is the Sama among the Puranas) means that just as the Sama Veda is supreme among the Vedas, so Åšrimad Bhagavatam is paramount among the PurÄnas. Therefore, Skanda PurÄna says: à¤¶à¤¤à¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤¥ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥­à¥§ à¥¥ à¤¨ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤—à¥‡à¤¹à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥Œ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤¸ à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¥€ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥‡ à¤¨ à¤¤à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤šà¤¾à¤§à¤®à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥­à¥© à¥¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤° à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤•à¤²à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¦à¤¶à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦ à¥¥ à¥­à¥ª à¥¥ à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤ à¥‡à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¤‚ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤…à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤«à¤²à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥­à¥« à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ In Kaliyuga, what is the value of collecting hundreds of thou- sands of other scriptures if one does not keep Åšrimad Bhagava- tam at home? How can a person be considered a Vaisnava in Kali- yuga if Srimad Bhagavatam finds no place in his house? Even if he 2 As in ParamÄtma Sandarbha 105. 143 11 PramÄÅ†a is a learned brÄhmaá¹‡a, such a person should be considered lower than a dog-eater. O learned brahmana Narada, wherever ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam is present in Kaliyuga, the Supreme Lord arrives there along with the devas. A person who faithfully recites one verse of Srimad Bhagavatam every day, O sage, attains the fruit of reading the eighteen PurÄnas. (Visnu-khanda 5.16.40-42, 44, 33)3 22.4 à¤¶à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ - à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤‚à¤¶à¤¦à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¤¶à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ The phrase sata-viccheda-samyutaá¸¥ (having hundreds of divi- sions) means that the Bhagavatam has three hundred and thirty- five chapters. The meaning of the rest of the passage [quoted in Anuccheda 21.1] is obvious. Thus, we conclude that at the present time, those who aspire to know the highest goal of life should deliberate on Åšrimad Bhagavatam alone. 22.5 à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¥§ | à¥¨à¥® ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥ªà¥¤à¥¨à¥«) - In Catur-varga-cintamani, Vrata-khanda 1.28, HemÃ¤dri cites the following verse and attributes it to Srimad Bhagavatam: à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥‚à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‚à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¥€ à¤¨ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤—à¥‹à¤šà¤°à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤® à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯à¤¸à¤¿ à¤®à¥‚à¤¢à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯ à¤à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤•à¥ƒà¤ªà¤¯à¤¾ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¬ à¥¥ 3 sataÅ¡o’tha sahasrais ca kim anyaiá¸¥ sastra-sangrahaiá¸¥ na yasya tiÅŸá¹­hate gehe Å›Ã¤stram bhagavatam kalau katham sa vaiá¹£á¹‡avo jÃ±eyaá¸¥ Å›astram bhÄgavatam kalau grhe na tiÅŸá¹­hate yasya sa vipraá¸¥ Å›vapacÄdhamaá¸¥ yatra yatra bhaved vipra sastram bhagavatam kalau tatra tatra harir yati tridaÅ›aiá¸¥ saha nÃ¤rada yah pathet prayato nityam slokam bhagavatam mune aá¹£á¹­Ädasa-puraá¹‡ÄnÄá¹ phalam prÃ¤pnoti mÄnavaá¸¥ 144 22 Åšrimad BhÄgavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature Seeing that women, sudras, and the unqualified among the twice- born classes were prevented even from hearing the Vedas, the great sage [Vyasa], moved by compassion, compiled the great historical narration called Mahabharata so that those who were unaware of how to act for ultimate good might also attain auspiciousness. (SB 1.4.25)* à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®- à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ - à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ HemÄdri uses this verse to demonstrate that Mahabharata is as valuable as the Vedas, and the phrase bhÄratÃ¤rtha-vinirnayah (Srimad Bhagavatam establishes the meaning of MahabhÄrata) should be explained in accordance with this view as indicating that Srimad Bhagavatam is the book in which Mahabharata’s mes- sage is conclusively defined and shown to be equal to that of the Vedas. 22.6 à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ " à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤- à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤¾ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹à¤½à¤¸à¥Œ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¥ â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ 1 Since the book named Srimad Bhagavatam, characterized as “a delineation of Ultimate Truth with reference to the Gayatri mantra,” is exclusively focused upon Bhagavan, it serves as a commentary on Gayatri, which is also intent solely upon Bhaga- vÃ¤n. This same point - that Srimad Bhagavatam is a commen- tary on the Gayatri mantra - is made in such statements as “The Bhagavatam delineates the path of Ultimate Truth with refer- ence to the Gayatri mantra” (Anuccheda 19.2). Furthermore, Agni PurÄna describes Bhagavan alone in the course of its exposition of the Gayatri mantra. stri-sÃ¼dra-dvija-bandhunam trayi na Å›ruti-gocarÄƒ karma-Å›reyasi mÃ¼á¸hÃ¤nÃ¤m Å›reya eva bhaved tha iti bharatam akhyanam ká¹›paya muninÄ ká¹›tam 145II Pramana 22.7 à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¦à¥€à¤¯à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¨à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ â€œà¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤œà¥‹ à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒâ€ (à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥- à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¥¨à¥§à¥®à¥¤à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤°à¤¾à¤¹ (à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¥¨à¥§à¥®à¥¤à¥­-à¥®) - Here is a concise overview of this explanation from Agni Purana: “That supracosmic light is known as the Supreme Brahman, because the word bhargas [in Gayatri] means [the divine] effulgenceâ€ (AP 216.3) 5 Agni PurÄna further states: à¤¤à¤œà¥à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥à¤œà¤—à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤‚ à¤•à¥‡à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤® à¤¶à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤ªà¤ à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¥¥ à¥­à¥­ à¥¥ à¤•à¥‡à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤•à¥‡à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¦à¥ˆà¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¹à¥‹à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¥‹ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤°à¥à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥® à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ That effulgence is ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u, who is the unconditional cause of cosmic creation, maintenance, and dissolution. Some people maintain that “effulgence” here refers instead to Åšiva, while oth- ers say it means Sakti. Some claim that it refers to the sun, and still others say Agni. Other devas too are invoked by brahma- nas who perform Vedic fire sacrifices (Agni-hotrÄ«s) at the time of uttering Gayatri. But it is ÅšrÄ« Viá¹£á¹‡u who is present in the forms of Agni and the other devas, and the Vedas sing of Him alone as the Absolute Truth, Brahman.
