(AP 216. 7-8 ) 6 22.8 à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° “à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ " à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¯à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ â€œà¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ˆ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¥â€ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ | à¥§à¥© | à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤š “à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¥ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ à¥¤ à¥§à¥© à¥¤ à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥‡à¤µà¤¾- à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¥ à¥¤ Later [in ParamÄtma Sandarbha, Anuccheda 104], while com - menting on the opening verse of the Bhagavatam, we will elabo- rate further on the view that the BhÄgavatam is a commentary taj-jyotiá¸¥ paramam brahma bhargas tejo yataá¸¥ smrtah â— taj-jyotir bhagavÄn visÅ†ur jagaj-janmadi-kÄranam Sivam kecit pathanti sma sakti-rupam pathanti ca kecit suryam kecid agnim daivatany agni-hotrinaá¸¥ agny-adi-rupo vismur hi vedadau brahma giyate 146 22 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature on Gayatri. Also, in one of the concluding verses of the BhÄga- vatam (SB 12.13.19), we find the adjectives pure (suddha), spot- less (vimala), free from grief (visoka), and immortal (amá¹›ta), qualifying the Supreme Truth (param satyam) [identified in the subsequent verse as Bhagavan Vasudeva] upon whom we are to meditate (dhimahi). This description exactly echoes the ensuing statement from Agni Purana, which is itself an explanation of Gayatri. This uniformity of description further substantiates the view that the BhÄgavatam is a commentary on Gayatri. The verse from Agni Purana is as follows: à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤¨à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤®à¤§à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¹à¤‚ à¤œà¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤® à¤¹à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¯à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥­à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ To awake to the post-liberated status, let us meditate (dhya- yema) on the Supreme Brahman (param brahma), who is eternal (nitya), pure (suddha), transcendental (para), ever-effulgent (nitya-bharga), and the final repository of inherent controlling agency (adhiÅ›vara). As we meditate, let us contemplate, “I am that light, the Supreme Truth.” (AP 216.6)” à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ “à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤°à¥à¤šà¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¯à¥‹à¤—à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥ƒà¤•à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¾ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ â€“ à¤…à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¥‡ à¤š à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ Here, the contemplation of oneself as identical to Brahman is meant to help the meditator attain fitness to worship the com- plete Truth, Bhagavan, following the principle, “One who is not of the nature of the Divine cannot worship the Divine.” The verb form dhyÄyema (let us meditate) signifies that “not only I, but all of us are implored to meditate.” 22.9 à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¤¦à¤¨à¥à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ â€œà¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤²à¥à¤•à¥â€ (à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿ à¥­ à¥¤ à¥§ à¥¤ à¥©à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤›à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¸à¤¸à¥‚à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¯ â€œà¤…à¤®à¤ƒâ€ à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥‹ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡ â€œà¥ “nityam suddham param brahma nitya-bhargam adhiÅ›varam aham jyotih param brahma dhyayema hi vimuktaye 147 II PramÄÅ†a à¤¨à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨à¥¤à¥¬à¥¤à¥¬à¥­) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿ à¤—à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¤à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¨ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤£à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥‹à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ According to this view, however, the [uninflected] word bharga that appears even in the Gayatri mantra is specifically that which terminates with the vowel a [since it has an alternate unin- flected stem terminating with the consonant s, i.e., bhargas]. The irregular accusative declension of bharga [in the mantra] as bhargas where bhargam might be expected can be explained as an instance of the type given in PANINI 7.1.39, which is intended for the analysis of Vedic texts. The sutra is supÄm su-luk-pÅ«rva- savarnacche-ya-da-dya-yÄjÄlaá¸¥, “by which the accusative suffix am may be replaced by the nominative su [from which the vowel u is dropped].” In the prose section of the Twelfth Canto of the Bhagava- tam (12.6.67-72), beginning om namas te, the sun is praised as the object of worship in Gayatri. We should understand that this passage refers to ParamÄtmÄ (the Supreme Self), who is immanent within the sun, rather than to the sun independently. Understood in this way, the statement is faultless. 22.10 à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥Œà¤¨à¤•à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ “à¤¬à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤¦à¤§à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‚à¤¹à¤‚ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¥‹ à¤¹à¤°à¥‡à¤ƒ” (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨à¥¤à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¨ à¤šà¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤²à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¾à¤¨à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤µà¤°à¥‡à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤š à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¥‡ à¤ªà¤°à¤¶à¤¬à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ Later in the Bhagavatam, Saunaka RÈ™i confirms this: “O SÅ«ta, kindly narrate to us, who are firmly established in faith, the glory of Sri Hari’s expansion as the Primal Self immanent within the sun” (SB 12.11.28). Similarly, one should not think that the word bharga (efful- gence) in Gayatri refers only to the presiding deity of the sun globe [i.e., Surya-deva], since the word varenya (transcenden- tal) in the Gayatri mantra and the word para (supreme) in the bruhi naá¸¥ Å›raddadhÄnÄnÄá¹ vyuham suryatmano hareá¸¥ 148 22 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature BhÄgavatam verses cited above [SB 1.1.1 and 12.13.19] have both been shown to refer ultimately to the transcendental opulence of the Supreme. 22.11 à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¥¨à¥§à¥¬à¥¤à¥§à¥¬ ) - Agni Purana similarly states: à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤²à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤® à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥®à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ This Primordial Person (PuruÅŸa), who is immanent within the sun, is to be directly self-apperceived (draá¹£á¹­avya) through the faculty of meditation, but the supreme destination is the tran- scendental abode of Sri VisÅ†u, which alone is eternal and ever- auspicious, being the Absolute Truth, Brahman. (AP 216.16)” à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤²à¥‹à¤•à¥€à¤œà¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤²à¤¯à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¸à¥‚à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤²à¥‡ à¤šà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‹ à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ - à¤‰à¤ªà¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤µà¥ˆà¤•à¥à¤£à¥à¤ à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤‚ à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ â€œà¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥â€ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤¿ à¥¤ “à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤µà¤®à¥â€ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¶à¥‚à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥‹ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿- à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ The meaning of this verse is as follows: This Primordial Per- son (Purusa), who Self-manifests as the Supreme Immanent Self (antaryÄmi) within the sun globe, is to be directly self- apperceived (draá¹£á¹­avya) through the faculty of meditation. The word draá¹£á¹­avya (to be seen) means that the PuruÅŸa is to be imme- diately devotionally recognized (upÃ¤sitavya) through medita- tion. The Purusa’s self-manifestation within the sun globe is to afford the inhabitants of the three divisions of the cosmos the opportunity to worship Him. This sun globe is destroyed at the time of dissolution, whereas the transcendental abode of ÅšrÄ« ViÅŸÅ†u, MahÄ-vaikuntha, is eternal, meaning that it is invari- able, being beyond the three phases of conditional time - past, dhyanena puruso’yam ca drastavyaá¸¥ surya-mandale satyam sada-Sivam brahma viÅŸnor yat paramaá¹h padam 149 11 PramÄÅ†a present, and future. That this abode is ever-auspicious means that it is utterly devoid of misfortune. The eternality and all- auspiciousness of ÅšrÄ« Visnu’s abode are due to the fact that it is directly the Absolute Truth, Brahman. 22.12 à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤°à¤£à¥‡ â€œà¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¥” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥- à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ (à¥¨à¥­à¥¨à¥¤à¥¬) à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ - After explaining Gayatri in this way, Agni Purana further elabo- rates on Gayatri in the section dealing with the characteristics of the PurÄnas, which contains the verse beginning yatradhiká¹›tya gayatrim. Thus, we say: à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¥‡à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤œà¤—à¤œà¥à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥®à¥§ à¥¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤¥à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤œà¤¯à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥®à¥¨ à¥¥ Agni Purana explains that the Gayatri mantra is intent exclu- sively upon Bhagavan, therein understood as the non-condi- tional source of cosmic creation, maintenance, and dissolution. Åšrimad Bhagavatam, characterized by the phrase, “which delin- eates the path of Ultimate Truth with reference to the Gayatri mantra,” is thus ever-glorious all over the earth.10 à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾ à¥¤ And so we have shown that the unfoldment of this scripture [Srimad Bhagavatam] proceeds with reference to Gayatri. 10 agneá¸¥ purÃ¤nar gayatrimá¹ sametya bhagavat-param bhagavantam tatra matva jagaj-janmadi-karanam yatradhiká¹›tya gayatrim iti laká¹£aá¹‡a-purvakam Srimad-bhagavatam saÅ›vat pá¹›thvyam jayati sarvataá¸¥ 150 22 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature 22.13 à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤®à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤š à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤•à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥‡- à¤ªà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤ªà¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ ( à¥¨à¥§à¥¬ à¥§-à¥¨ ) - Still, the statement made earlier [in Anuccheda 20.1] â€“ that the subject of the Bhagavatam is the Sarasvata-kalpa [a day of BrahmÄ, or the scripture related to Sarasvati] - is appropriate, because Gayatri is a manifestation of Sarasvati, as a special ver- bal expression establishing the truth of Bhagavan. Thus, Agni Purana says about Gayatri: à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¿ à¤­à¤°à¥à¤—à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¥à¥ˆà¤µ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤—à¤¾à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€ à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥€ à¤¯à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤š à¥¥ à¥®à¥© à¥¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤¿à¤¨à¥€ à¤¸à¤¾ à¤¸à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€ à¥¥ à¥®à¥ª à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ This mantra is called Gayatri [the singer], because it sings about (gÄyati) [or delineates] the Vedic mantras, the scriptures, the effulgent One [the Self-existing and Self- illuminated Lord], and the vital life system. It is called SÄvitrÄ« [the vivifier], because it reveals ÅšrÄ« SavitÄ, the animator of all life. And it is called Saras- vati [constituting the flow of speech], because it is the essence of speech. (AP 216.1-2 ) 11 22.14 à¤…à¤¥ à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾ “à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒâ€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¬à¥ƒà¤‚à¤¹à¤£à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤šà¥ à¤šà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ “à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥â€ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤ƒ” à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¤µà¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤  à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤à¥à¤šà¤¿à¤¦à¤¾à¤ªà¤¾à¤¤à¤¤à¥‹ à¤°à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¸à¥€ à¤œà¥à¤·à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥ˆà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥€à¤¤- à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤½à¤ªà¤¿ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤•à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‡à¤¨ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ (à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¤‚à¤¶à¥‡ à¥© | à¥§à¥©à¥¨ à¥§à¥¯à¥« ) - Now we will resume our sequential explanation of the terms in the passage quoted above from Garuda PurÄna [Anuccheda 21.1]: gayatry-ukthÃ¤ni sastrani bhargaá¹ prÄnÄms tathaiva ca tatah smrteyam gayatri sÃ¤vitri yata eva ca prakÄÅ›ini sÄƒ savitur vÃ¤g-rupatvÄt sarasvati 151 II PramÄÅ†a The phrase vedÃ¤rtha-paribá¹›mhitaá¸¥, which means that Srimad BhÄgavatam explains and expands the meaning of the Vedas, is supported by the following statement from MahÄbhÄrata (Adi- parva 1.267): “One should supplement the Vedas with the Itihasas and PurÄÅ†as.” The phrase purÄá¹‡ÄnÄá¹ sÃ¤ma-rupaá¸¥ means that just as the Sama Veda is supreme among the Vedas, so Åšrimad Bhagavatam is paramount among the PurÄÅ†as. The idea here is as follows: Although each division of the Vedas - karma-kÄá¹‡á¸a, jÃ±Äna-kÄá¹‡á¸a, and upÄsanÄ-kÄá¹‡á¸a- propounds its respective path, the Sama Veda reconciles the statements of these apparently conflicting divisions by show- ing that their message is one. Similarly, although some of the PurÄÅ†as appear to be tainted with the gunas of conditional becoming (rajas) and stasis (tamas) and hence don’t seem to pro- pound Ultimate Truth, Åšrimad Bhagavatam demonstrates that all of the PurÄnas culminate in ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan alone, upon whom the BhÄgavatam is exclusively fixed. Thus, it is said: à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡ à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¯à¤£à¥‡ à¤šà¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥‡ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¥¤ à¤†à¤¦à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤š à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤° à¤—à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥®à¥« à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ Throughout the Vedas, RÄmÄyaá¹‡a, the Puranas, and MahÄbhÄ- rata, ÅšrÄ« Hari is glorified everywhere, in the beginning, middle, and end. (Hari-vamsa Purana 3.132.95)12 à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤š à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤°à¥à¤­à¥‡ à¥¤ This we will demonstrate later, in Paramatma Sandarbha13 22.15 à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‹à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ “à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥ˆ à¤¯à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤­à¤¾à¤¸à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¯à¤®à¥â€ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ | à¥§à¥© | à¥§à¥¯) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¸à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾à¤°- à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¥‡à¤£ à¤œà¥à¤à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¶à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¥à¤›à¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ - à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤­à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¨ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®- 12 13 vede rÄmÄyaá¹‡e caiva purane bharate tatha adav ante ca madhye ca hariá¸¥ sarvatra giyate Anuccheda 104 152 22 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤šà¤•à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¦à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‡ “à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¤¸à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥” à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¸à¤¿à¤‚à¤¹à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤¢à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤Ÿà¥€à¤•à¤¾à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ The next phrase from the Garuda Purana verse [Anuccheda 21.1] is “Srimad Bhagavatam is the direct utterance of the Supreme Abso- lute, ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan” (sÄká¹£Äd-bhagavatoditaá¸¥). This is confirmed in the verse near the end of the Bhagavatam, wherein it is said, “We meditate upon the Supreme Lord, who spoke this ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam to Brahma” (SB 12.13.19). We will not elaborate here on the phrase “Srimad Bhagava- tam contains hundreds of divisions” (Å›ata-viccheda-samyutaá¸¥) because its discussion may unnecessarily increase the size of this book. In this way, it has been shown that Srimad Bhagavatam is the emperor of all scriptures. It is thus highly appropriate that ÅšrÄ«- dhara SvÄmi has interpreted the phrase hema-simha-samanvita [in his commentary to SB 12.13.13] to mean “mounted on a golden throne” [although literally it would mean “along with a golden lion”]. 22.16 à¤…à¤¤à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µà¤¾à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤µà¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤š à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¥€à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œ à¤¶à¤¤à¤¶à¥‹à¤½à¤¥ à¤¸à¤¹à¤¸à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¤¿à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥ˆà¤ƒâ€ (à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤—à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¥§à¥¬à¥¤à¥ªà¥¦ ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤µà¤¿- à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ Therefore, concluding that Srimad Bhagavatam is the preem- inent scripture and the only one that is imperative for us to study, Skanda Purana states, “What need is there of accumu- lating hundreds and thousands of other scriptures” (ViÅŸnu- khanda 5.16.40)?14 It is thus established without any doubt that at present those who aspire to know the Absolute Truth should deliberate on Åšrimad Bhagavatam alone. [This is a reconfirmation of the same statement made in Anuccheda 22.4.] 14 SataÅ›o’tha sahasraiÅ› ca kim anyaiá¸¥ Å›Ã¤stra-sangrahaiá¸¥ 153 II PramaÅ†a Commentary IN THE PREVIOUS ANUCCHEDA, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi quoted three verses from Garuda Purana. The first of the three was explained in that anuccheda, and here he goes on to explain the other two. He first quotes a Bhagavatam verse (SB 3.5.12) and then another (SB 1.4.25), which also appears in Hemadri’s Catur-varga-cintamani, an authori- tative thirteenth century work on Dharma-sastra dealing with such subjects as vratas (vows), dana (charity), Å›rÃ¤ddha (memorial ritu- als), and kala (sacred time). Jiva Gosvami’s intention in quoting these verses is to show that Mahabharata is equal to the Vedas. In this part of Catur-varga-cintamani, HemÄdrÄ« raises a question about the liberation of those who are not twice-born: Since they do not have access to the Vedas, which bestow knowledge of Brahman, and since knowledge of Brahman is required for liberation, how can they attain final release? To resolve this question, he quotes the stri-sÃ¼dra-dvijabandhunam verse (SB 1.4.25), which describes how VedavyÄsa wrote Mahabharata to address this very problem. The first of the two Bhagavatam verses cited also states that ÅšrÄ«la Vyasa compiled Mahabharata for the benefit of humanity in general: Your friend, the great sage Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a-dvaipayana Vyasa, composed His great work, Mahabharata, with the intention of describing the transcendental qualities of Åšri Bhagavan. In this work, He has drawn the attention of the mass of people to the descriptions of Lord Hari by embedding them within the framework of mundane topics. (SB 3.5.12)15 To fulfill His intention, Vyasa included Bhagavad Gita in the Mahabharata. Since Mahabharata is considered equal to the Vedas in purpose as is evident from the second verse (SB 1.4.25), and as corroborated by Hemadri - we can deduce that the Vedas also aim at glorifying Bhagavan. This being the case, the Gayatri mantra, which embodies the essence of the Vedas, should also refer to the Supreme Personal 15 munir vivaksur bhagavad-gunÃ¤nÃ¤á¹ sakhÃ¤pi te bharatam Ã¤ha ká¹›á¹£á¹‡aá¸¥ yasmin ná¹›á¹‡Äm gramya-sukhÄnuvadair matir grhitÄƒ nu hareá¸¥ kathÄyÄm 154 22 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature Absolute, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. It is with this understanding that Skanda Purana says that Srimad Bhagavatam, which glorifies Bhagavan at every step, is based on Gayatri. Indeed, this is one of the distinctive characteristics of Srimad Bhagavatam. In ParamÃ¤tma Sandarbha (Anuccheda 104), Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi will analyze the first verse of Srimad Bhagavatam in terms of its being an explanation of the Gayatri mantra. Gayatri is explained in one of the concluding verses of the Bhagavatam (SB 12.13.19, as claborated in Paramatma Sandarbha, Anuccheda 105) as well. This combination of indications from the beginning and ending verses makes it indisputably clear that the purpose of Srimad BhÄgavatam is to delineate the truth of Bhagavan. The prevalent understanding among traditional Vedic scholars is that Gayatri is meant for worshiping either the sun god or unqual- ified Brahman. Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi here establishes, however, that the real meaning of Gayatri is the worship of ÅšrÄ« ViÅŸÅ†u, who is non- different from ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. To support his view, he cites Agni PurÄÅ†a, which gives ÅšrÄ«la Vyasa’s opinion on the meaning of Gayatri. In ViÅŸÅ†u-dharmottara Purana, King Vajra asks MÃ¤rkandeya Rá¹£i why Gayatri is chanted in Vaisnava rituals if its presiding deity is the sun god. MÃ¤rkandeya replies that Gayatri refers to ÅšrÄ« Viá¹£Å†u and then proceedes to show how each word of Gayatri is related to Him. He concludes with this verse: By chanting Gayatri, a person desirous of material gain achieves the phenomenal object of his desire, while a person aspiring for liberation attains to that essential state. But the worshiper who is devoid of desires attains the supreme abode of ÅšrÄ« Visnu. (Visnu- dharmottara Purana, Prathama-khanda)16 It would not be possible to attain the Lord’s abode by meditat- ing on Gayatri if it did not in fact imply the worship of ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u; this accords with Bhagavan’s statement in GITA 9.25 that “Only My worshiper attains Me.” Thus, Gayatri and the first verse of 16 kama-kamo labhet kÃ¤mam gati-kÄmas tu sad-gatim akÄmas tu tad avapnoti yad visnoá¸¥ paramam padam 15511 PramÄÅ†a the BhÄgavatam are in complete agreement, because they are both meditations on the Supreme Personal Absolute, Bhagavan. The verse cited from Agni Purana in Anuccheda 22.8, advising us to meditate on the self as nondifferent from Brahman, is also in agreement with the Bhagavatam and Gayatri. The verse is meant to impress upon us our true spiritual identity and to teach us a meditational process that establishes us in that identity, beyond the empiric or egoic self-reference. This kind of meditation, there- fore, is simply to elicit the fitness, or in other words, the funda- mental state of being, that alone makes possible the true worship of the Supreme Absolute, Bhagavan. Later in Tattva Sandarbha (Anucchedas 53 and 60), ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi will discuss in greater detail the qualitative oneness of the jiva-brahman with the Supreme Brahman. In Anucchedas 22.9-11, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« discusses the relation- ship between Gayatri and the sun. Åšrimad Bhagavatam (12.6.67-72) records sage Yajnavalkya’s prayers in praise of the sun or sun god, and texts 67-69 explain the three legs of the Gayatri mantra. From these prayers it may seem that Gayatri is also meant for glorifying the sun god, but Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi explains that Yajnavalkya is not worshiping the sun god independently; rather, he is worshiping the Supreme Immanent Self (ParamÄtmÄ) dwelling within the sun god. Generally, people hail a taxi driver by calling out “Taxi!” not “Taxi driver!” for they regard the driver and his taxi as one unit. Similarly, Yajnavalkya worships the sun god while considering the “vehicle” (the sun god) and the “driver” (ParamÄtmÄ) as one. This explana- tion by Jiva GosvÄmi finds confirmation in ÅšrÄ« Saunaka’s question to SÅ«ta GosvÄmÄ« that led to the recitation of Yajnavalkya’s prayers. Saunaka explicitly requests “to hear about Åšri Hari, the Supreme Self (ParamÄtmÄ) immanent within the sun” (SB 12.11.28). BrÄhmaá¹‡as customarily chant Gayatri at dawn and at dusk while facing the sun. In this way they meditate on the Supreme Lord through His energies. The logical principle at work here is called candra-Å›Äkha-nyaya, or “the example of the branch and the moon.” The idea is that to show someone the moon, you may first ask him to look at a tree branch, from which you may then draw his attention 156 22 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature to the moon beyond the branch. Similarly, the process of meditat- ing on Bhagavan may include allowing one’s attention to be drawn to Bhagavan through His energies, such as the sun. It is not always practical or advisable for a twice-born brahmana to carry an actual image of God, but he must still perform his daily duty of meditat- ing on Him at dawn and dusk. So, the Vedas enjoin that he should meditate on Bhagavan through the medium of the ever-present sun, always remembering that beyond the effulgent sun is ÅšrÄ« VisÅ†u. This is called pratikopÄsana (symbolic worship). ÅšrÄ«la JÄ«va GosvÄmi concludes his discussion of the relation- ship of Srimad Bhagavatam with Gayatri in Anuccheda 22.13, where he quotes a statement from Agni Purana that Gayatri is so-called because it sings (gayati) or illuminates the glories of the Supreme Lord and protects (trÄyate) the chanter by fixing his mind on the Lord. Gayatri is also related with the sun, because one of the words used in Gayatri is Savita, a name for the sun god meaning one who animates all life. Moreover, another name for Gayatri is SÄvitrÄ«, the daughter of the sun god. Additionally, Gayatri is also Saras- vati, the presiding deity of speech, because it is the sound repre- sentation of Bhagavan. Skanda Purana therefore states (quoted in Anuccheda 20.1) that the Bhagavatam is based on Gayatri (Saras- vati); it is the sound representation of Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, and it recounts events that occurred during the Sarasvata-kalpa. This implies that the Bhagavatam’s narrations glorify only Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. In Anuccheda 22.14, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmÄ« resumes his analy- sis of each phrase of the verses from Garuda Purana quoted in Anuccheda 21. In these verses, Srimad Bhagavatam is described as the Sama Veda among the PurÄÅ†as. In GITA 10.22, ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a says, “Of all the Vedas, I am the Sama Veda.” Here, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a indicates that since the Sama Veda is the best of all the Vedas, containing beautiful prayers glorifying the Supreme Lord, it therefore represents Him. Such glorification of the Lord is, after all, the ultimate purpose of the Vedas, as SB 1.2.28 states: vasudeva-para vedaá¸¥. Like the Vedas, the PurÄÅ†as also glorify various deities, although their underlying purpose is the glorification of Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, and Srimad Bhagavatam is the Sama Veda among the PurÄÅ†as because it focuses exclusively on 157 II Pramana Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. The BhÄgavatam reconciles the other Puranas. Thus, Skanda Purana declares that by studying Åšrimad Bhagavatam, one derives the benefit of studying all the PurÄÅ†as. The very name Åšrimad Bhagavatam indicates its paramount posi- tion. ÅšrÄ«mat means “endowed with beauty, luster, and opulence,” and bhÄgavata means “related to (or, ‘of the nature of’) Bhagavan.” Srimad Bhagavatam is thus the most beautiful literary creation because it describes the beautiful pastimes of the Supreme Person. Åšrimat also means “opulent.” Srimad Bhagavatam is most opulent because it is identical with Bhagavan, the original Supreme Person, who is replete with all opulences. Sata-viccheda-samyuta literally means that the Bhagavatam “has hundreds of sections.” Although Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi does not com- ment in detail upon this phrase here, we may point out that most editions of the Bhagavatam have 335 chapters, divided into twelve cantos, but some commentators acknowledge only 332 chapters. They claim that chapters 12 to 14 of the Tenth Canto are interpo- lations. However, great authorities such as ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« and Vopadeva have accepted these three chapters and commented on them, and Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmÄ« has done so as well. The three chapters in question describe the killing of Aghasura and ÅšrÄ« Brahma’s bewilderment by Krsna. In Chapter 12 of the Twelfth Canto, SÅ«ta GosvÄmÄ« gives a list of the lilÃ¤s of Bhagavan, and in the twenty-eighth text of that list, he mentions the killing of Aghasura and ÅšrÄ« Brahma’s bewilderment. The inclusion of the pastimes from the three disputed chapters clearly indicates that these chapters have a place in the BhÄgavatam. Thus, in the opinion of Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi, the BhÄgavatam contains 335 chapters, since it would otherwise fall short of eighteen thousand verses. Commenting on the phrase hema-simha-samanvita,” which lit- erally means “together with a golden lion,” ÅšrÄ«la Sridhara SvÄmÄ« says that simha (lion) indicates a simha-asana (a deity’s throne in the shape of a lion). In other words, Srimad Bhagavatam recommends “The same phrase is found both in the Matsya Purana verses quoted in Anuccheda 19.2 as well as in SB 12.13.13. ÅšrÄ«dhara Svami’s gloss is found in the Bhavartha-dipika to the latter verse. 158 22 Åšrimad Bhagavatam Is the Essence of All Vedic Literature that one mount the Bhagavatam on a lion-shaped golden throne and then donate it. A golden throne is not recommended for any other PurÄÅ†a. ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi concludes, therefore, that just as the lion is the emperor of all animals, Åšrimad Bhagavatam is the emperor of all scriptures. Consequently, it is also the sovereign ruler among all pramÄÅ†as, and, as Skanda Purana recommends, a person wishing to know the Absolute Reality need not study any other scripture. Next, Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmi describes how all the great ÄcÄryas and scholars of the past held Srimad Bhagavatam in the highest esteem. 159 Anuccheda 23 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun 23.1 I à¥¨à¥© à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤ªà¤¿ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¤à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ “à¤•à¤²à¥Œ à¤¨à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤· à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤•à¥‹à¤½à¤§à¥à¤¨à¥‹- à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ " ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§ | à¥© | à¥ªà¥ª ) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤•à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤•à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¤¦à¥ à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤µà¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤•à¤¾à¤¶à¤•à¤¤à¥à¤µ- à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¹à¤¯à¤¶à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤ªà¤à¥à¤šà¤°à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡ à¤¶à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‡ à¤—à¤£à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤§à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¸à¤¾à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¾à¤šà¥ à¤›à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¹à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿- à¤µà¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥à¤•à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¹à¤‚à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤¹à¥ƒà¤¦à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤ƒ | à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤«à¤²à¤¹à¤°à¤¿à¤²à¥€à¤²à¤¾à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤µà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤¬à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤§à¤¾ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤®à¤¹à¤¾- à¤¨à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ THUS, while there are many authoritative scriptures, it is specif- ically Å›rimad Bhagavatam that has been singled out with the statement, “For those in Kaliyuga whose vision is impaired, this PurÄna has now arisen like the sun " ( SB 1.3.43) ! This comparison of the Bhagavatam to the sun indicates that without its light, other scriptures cannot fully illuminate the Absolute Truth. The Hayasirá¹£a-paÃ±caratra, in its chapter classifying vari- ous scriptures, describes the Tantra-bhÄgavata as essentially a commentary on Srimad Bhagavatam. Among the direct com- mentaries on the Bhagavatam are the Hanumad-bhÄá¹£ya, VÄsanÄ- bhÄsya, Sambandhokti, Vidvat-kÄmadhenu, Tattva-dÄ«pikÄ, BhÄvÄ- rtha-dipikÄ, Paramahamsa-priyÄ, and Suka - hrdayÄ. There are also many essays written about Srimad Bhagavatam, such as MuktÄ phala, Hari-lilÄ, and Bhakti-ratnÄvali. All these works 1 kalau naÅŸta-dá¹›Å›am eÅŸa purÃ¤narko’dhunoditaá¸¥ 2 None of these commentaries are available at present except for BhavÃ¤rtha-dipika of ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ«. 160 23 Åšrimad Bhagavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun have been produced by the most eminent thinkers of their respective philosophical schools. 23.2 à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤š à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¨à¥à¤¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¥‡ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¥‡ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¥€à¤¯à¤¤à¤²à¥à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¤£à¤§à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¶- à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤ªà¤°à¤¿à¤¶à¥‡à¤·à¤–à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤•à¤¾à¤²à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‡ à¤š à¤•à¤²à¤¿à¤¯à¥à¤—à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥‡ â€œà¤•à¤²à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¸à¤­à¤¾à¤œà¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒâ€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥«à¥¤à¥©à¥¬) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨à¥‹à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ªà¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤§à¤°à¥à¤® à¤à¤µ à¤•à¤²à¤¾à¤µà¤™à¥à¤—à¥€- à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¤ Srimad Bhagavatam is also glorified in the Dana-khanda section of Hemadri’s Catur-varga-cintamani. His chapter entitled “Giv- ing PurÄnas in Charity” praises Srimad Bhagavatam by noting that it possesses the defining characteristics specified in Matsya PurÄna 53.20-22. In the PariseÈ™a-khanda of the same book, in the Kala-nirnaya section, where Hemadri ascertains the appropriate dharmic path for Kaliyuga, he quotes the Bhagavatam verse beginning kalim sabhÄjayanty ÄryÄ (SB 11.5.36 ). In this way he recognizes as appropriate for this age only that dharmic path that is established in Åšrimad Bhagavatam. 23.3 à¤…à¤¥ à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¥ˆà¤µà¤²à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤°à¤®à¥à¤¯ à¤­à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤–à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‡à¤¨ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤®à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤¿ à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤œ- à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¥ à¤®à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¯à¤¦à¤ªà¥Œà¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¯à¤‚ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¤‚ à¤­à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤šà¤¾à¤²à¤¯à¤¤à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤°à¤¾à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¤à¤¯à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥‡à¤¨ à¤µà¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤—à¥‹à¤ªà¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤¹à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤•à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¦à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¿à¤¤à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¦à¤°à¥à¤¶- à¤¨à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤µà¥à¤°à¤œà¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¥à¤°à¤œà¤•à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤°à¥€à¤µà¤¸à¤¨à¤šà¥Œà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤—à¥‹à¤µà¤¿à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¤¾à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤•à¤¾à¤¦à¥Œ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾ à¤¤à¤Ÿà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¥€à¤­à¥‚à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤µà¤šà¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¾à¤«à¤²à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¯ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¥ It is widely acknowledged that ÅšrÄ« SankarÄcÄrya is a divine descent (avatÄra) of Lord Siva. In Srimad Bhagavatam it is revealed that the bliss of [self-radiant unconditional acausal] devotion surpasses even the joy of pure consciousness liberated from subject-object dualism (kaivalya ). Based on such indica- tions, SankarÄcÄrya considered Åšrimad Bhagavatam to embody 161 II PramÄÅ†a a truth far beyond even his own doctrine. Consequently, he dared not interpret the Bhagavatam, for he recognized it as an exposition of Vedanta that is beyond human origin. As we shall explain later, ÅšrÄ« Bhagavan, in order to conceal His own identity, ordered SankarÄcÄrya to propagate his doctrine of rad- ical nondualism (Advaitavada). Yet, to make his own words fruitful [by way of reference to Srimad Bhagavatam], SankarÄcÄ- rya touched on it indirectly, describing in his Govindaá¹£á¹­aka and other hymns certain pastimes of ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a that are related only in the Bhagavatam. These include mother Yasoda’s amazement at seeing Krsna’s universal form and His stealing the clothes of the young damsels of Vraja. Commentary ALTHOUGH THERE ARE numerous works of Vedic literature, when Åšaunaka RÅŸi questioned ÅšrÄ« SÅ«ta GosvÄmÄ« about where dharma would take shelter now that ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a had returned to His own abode (SB 1.1.23), SÅ«ta compared ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam to the sun, because it self-reveals the illuminating Absolute Truth that can dissipate the dense darkness of Kaliyuga. The analogy here is as fol- lows: When the sun rises, rogues and thieves hide, while ordinary people are relieved of fear and become active. Similarly, when con- sciousness is turned in full aural reception toward Åšrimad Bhagava- tam, lust and greed, which plunder one’s opportunity to realize the self, find no more standing in the heart, and one becomes qualified to participate in the service of the Supreme Lord. It is because of this self-illuminating power of Srimad Bhagava- tam that it is held in reverence by great saints and thinkers who have written commentaries and essays on it. Most of these com- mentaries listed in this anuccheda are not available at present, likely because they were eclipsed by the most popular commentary, the BhÄvÄrtha-dipika of Sridhara Svami, written probably in the four- teenth century. Vopadeva wrote Paramahamsa-priya, MuktÄ-phala, and Hari-lila. Bhakti-ratnavali was compiled by Visnu Puri. These latter works are all still available for interested readers today. 162 4 23 Åšrimad Bhagavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun Åšrila Jiva GosvÄmÄ« again refers to the Catur-varga-cintamani (Dana-khanda 7) of Hemadri, who recommends that one donate Srimad Bhagavatam after mounting it on a golden throne, and who glorifies it for having the defining characteristics described in the Matsya Purana (see Anuccheda 19). While determining the dharmic path for this age in the fourteenth chapter of Catur-varga-cintamani, Parisesa-khanda, verse 8, Hemadri quotes Srimad Bhagavatam: Those who are cultured in spiritual wisdom, who can perceive virtue within everything, and who thus extract the essence of all things, extol the essential value of this Age of Kali, in which one can attain all goals aspired for by human beings simply by the performance of sarikirtana. (SB 11.5.36)3 Commenting on the word sankirtana, HemÃ¤dri declares that hari-sankirtana is the only way to reach perfection. Then he quotes the next verse: Indeed, for human beings wandering in this material world, there is no benefit higher than the singing of Bhagavan’s Names, by which one attains supreme peace and cessation of the cycle of birth and death. (SB 11.5.37)* In this way, HemÃ¤dri recognizes the authority of Srimad Bhaga- vatam in the matter of establishing the principles of dharma for Kaliyuga. SankarÄcÄrya respected Srimad Bhagavatam both by not com- menting on it and by composing prayers based on its narrations. One such prayer is his Govindaá¹£á¹­aka: satyam jÃ±Änam anantam nityam anÄkÄÅ›aá¹ paramÄkÄÅ›aá¹ gostha-prÃ¤ngana-ringana-lolam anayasaá¹ paramayasam mÃ¤yÃ¤-kalpita-nÃ¤nÃ¤-kÃ¤ram anÃ¤kÃ¤ram bhuvanÃ¤kÃ¤raá¹ ká¹£amÄyÄ nÃ¤tham anatham praá¹‡amata govindam paramanandam kalim sabhÃ¤jayanty Ã¤ryÃ¤ guna-jÃ±aá¸¥ sÃ¤ra-bhaginaá¸¥ yatra sankirtanenaiva sarvah svartho ‘bhilabhyate na hy atah paramo lÃ¤bho dehinam bhramyatam iha yato vindeta paramam santim nasyati samsá¹›tiá¸¥ 163 164 II PramÄÅ†a May the self be devotionally offered to ÅšrÄ« Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. He is primordial being, consciousness devoid of limit, and eternal. Though beyond the limitations of space, He is the transcendental space of all- accomodation. Though His rolling and frolicking in the courtyards of Vraja involved no exertion at all, it was the transcendental exer- tion of self-manifested play. Though formless, He manifests vari- ous forms fashioned by maya, including the form of the universe. Though fully competent as the shelter of all existence, He appears to need [His mother’s] shelter. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 1) mytsnÃ¤m atsiheti yasoda-tÃ¤á¸ana-saiÅ›ava-santrÃ¤sam vyÃ¤dita-vaktrÃ¤lokita-lokaloka-caturdaÅ›a-lokalim loka-traya-pura-mula-stambham lokalokam anÄlokaá¹ lokeÅ›am parameÅ›am pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to Sri Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. Though He is the sup- reme master of the universe, He seemed to become frightened like an ordinary infant when Mother Yasoda chastised Him for eating a clump of earth. When she asked, “Have You been eating mud?” He opened His mouth to prove He had not- and showed her that He encompassed the fourteen planetary systems, including Lokaloka Mountain. He is the supporting pillar for this city-like universe of the three worlds. Though He is beyond all vision, He is the transcendental source of everyone’s vision. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 2) trai-vistapa-ripu-vira-ghnam ká¹£iti-bhara-ghnam bhava-roga-ghnam kaivalyaá¹ navanÄ«tÄhÄram anÃ¤hÃ¤raá¹ bhuvanÃ¤hÄram vaimalya-sphuÈ›a-ceto-vá¹›tti-viseÅŸÃ¤bhasam anabhÃ¤saá¹ saivam kevala-santam pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to Åšri Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. He relieves the earth of its burden by killing the demonic heroes who are enemies of the devas. He is liberation itself, because He terminates the dis- ease of material existence. Though He is altogether beyond the need to eat, still He eats butter, and He also devours the whole uni- verse at the time of cosmic dissolution. Though distinct from all the shadow manifestations of this world, He manifests in the supracog- nitive functions of pure consciousness, free from material taint. He 23 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun is all-auspicious and the unalterable peace of liberated existence. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 3) gopalam bhi-lila-vigraha-gopalar kula-gopalam gopi-khelana-govardhana-dhá¹›ta-lila-lÃ¤lita-gopÄlam gobhir nigadita-govinda-sphuta-nÃ¤mÃ¤nam bahu-nÃ¤mÃ¤nam gopi-go-cara-dÃºram pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to Åšri Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. He is Gopala, the pro- tector of the cows, who appeared in the form of a cowherd boy to enact His pastimes on earth, and who thus lived as one amongst the cowherd clan. He is Gopala who enacts sublime pastimes, such as His amorous dalliances with the youthful cowherd women and His lifting Govardhana Hill to protect the cowherd people. Even the cows called Him by the name Govinda, and so He has unlimited names. He is distinct among the cowherd boys and is beyond sense perception. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 4) gopi-mandala-gosthi-bhedam bhedavastham abhedabham sasvad go-khura-nirdhÃ¼todgat-dhuli-dhÅ«sara-saubhagyam Å›raddha-bhakti-grhitanandam acintyaá¹ cintita-sad-bhavam cintamani-mahimanam pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to ÅšrÄ« Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. For His divine lilÃ¤ He becomes the source of the gopis’ division (bheda) into different groups. So, although He is one without distinction (abheda), He is simultaneously the source of all distinction (bhedavastha). He considers it His good fortune to be always smeared with the dust raised by the cows’ hooves. He experiences bliss derived from the intuitive faith and unconditional devotion of His devotees. Though He is beyond the power of cognition, His pastimes are the object of pure contemplation, and so His glories are of the nature of a transcendental thought-gem. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 5) snana-vyakula-yoÅŸid-vastram upÄdÄyÄgam uparÃ¼á¸ham vyÃ¤ditsantiratha dig-vastra hy upadatum upÃ¤kará¹£antam A gem that yields whatever desire is held in thought. 165166 11 PramÄÅ†a nirdhuta dvaya-soka-vimoham buddham buddher antaá¸¥-stham satta-mÃ¤tra-sariram pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to ÅšrÄ« Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. He stole the bathing damsels’ clothes and climbed a tree with them, and when the naked maidens asked for their clothes back, He told them to come closer. He dispels the diad of lamentation and delusion. He is wisdom as well as He who is realized through the wisdom faculty. He is the embodiment of pure existence. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 6) kÄntaá¹ kÄraá¹‡a-kÄraá¹‡am adim anÃ¤dim kalam anabhÃ¤saá¹ kalindi-gata-kaliya-sirasi muhur muhuá¸¥ suná¹›tyantam kÄlam kala-kalÃ¤titam kalitÃ¤Å›eÅŸam kali-dosa-ghnam kala-traya-gati-hetum pranamata govindaá¹ paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to ÅšrÄ« Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. He is all-attracting beauty. He is the transcendental source condition that makes pos- sible the chain of causal arising. He is the beginning, yet is without beginning, for He is altogether free from the superimposition of time. He danced wonderfully on the hoods of the Kaliya serpent in the Yamuna. Though He is time, He is beyond all divisions of time, because the calculation of Him in terms of a single unit of experience is impossible, being without end or limit. He destroys the defects of Kaliyuga, and He is the source of the passage of time as past, present, and future. (GovindÃ¤á¹£á¹­aka 7) vá¹›ndavana-bhuvi vá¹›ndÄraka-gana-vá¹›ndaradhyam vande’ham kundabhamala-manda-smera-sudhanandam suhá¹›d-anandam vandyaseá¹£a-maha-muni-mÄƒnasa-vandyananda-pada-dvandvam vandyaseá¹£a-gunadbhim pranamata govindam paramanandam May the self be devotionally offered to Åšri Govinda, who is inher- ently of the nature of transcendental bliss. I bow down to Him, who is worshiped in the land of Vá¹›ndÄvana by all the devas and by ÅšrÄ«- mati Vá¹›ndadevi. His pure and beautiful smile emanates bliss like a kunda flower pouring forth nectar. He is the source of transcen- dental ecstasy for His cowherd friends. Unlimited venerable great sages worship His blissful lotus feet within their hearts, for He is 23 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun the reservoir of endless worshipable qualities. (GovindÄá¹£á¹­aka 8) govindaá¹£á¹­akam etad adhite govindÃ¤rpita-cetÄƒ yaá¸¥ govindÃ¤cyuta madhava viÅŸno gokula-nayaka ká¹›á¹£á¹‡eti govindanghri-saroja-dhyana-sudha-jala-dhauta-samastaghaá¸¥ govindam paramanandamá¹›tam antaá¸¥-sthaá¸¥ sa tamabhyeti A person who has fully imbibed this Govindaá¹£á¹­aka [through regular recitation and reflection], whose consciousness has been devo- tionally offered to Govinda, and who sweetly chants, “O Govinda, Acyuta, Madhava, ViÅŸÅ†u, Gokula-nayaka, Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a,” thus cleansing away all his sins with the ambrosial water of meditation on the lotus feet of Åšri Govinda- such a person certainly attains ÅšrÄ« Govinda, the supreme everlasting bliss, present as interior even to consciousness itself. (Govindaá¹£á¹­aka 9) ÅšrÄ« Govinda ordered Åšiva to descend as Sankara to propagate radical nondualism. Consequently, SankarÄcÄrya wrote Advaita- vÃ¤da commentaries on Vedanta-sutra, on eleven of the principal Upanisads, on Bhagavad Gita, and on Sri ViÅŸÅ†u-sahasra-nÄma. He did not interpret Srimad Bhagavatam, however, because he considered it very dear to Bhagavan and His devotees, and also nondifferent from Bhagavan. There can be no doubt about Lord Siva’s apprecia- tion of the BhÄgavatam, since in the Twelfth Canto he is described as the greatest Vaisnava (SB 12.13.16). As such, he must have been fully aware that it is the supreme pramana, and so out of respect he did not interpret it. From Padma Purana we learn how ÅšrÄ« Visnu ordered Åšiva to propagate a radical version of nondualism (i.e., a version that can accommodate oneness only and not distinction): O Åšiva, by formulating your own speculative scriptures, you must turn people’s attention away from Me to keep Me concealed from their view. By doing so, this creation may be perpetuated on and on. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 71.107) svagamaiá¸¥ kalpitais tvam ca janan mad-vimukhÄn kuru mam ca gopaya yena syat sá¹›á¹£á¹­ir eÅŸottarottara 167 11 PramÄÅ†a The import of this order is as follows: When Lord Buddha’s teach- ings were predominant in India, people grew contemptuous of the Vedas and Vedic rituals. They became sunya-vÄdÄ«s, voidists or non- essentialists, and Vedic religious practices decreased almost to nil. In this condition, people were not prepared to hear seriously about the Absolute as a personal God, about His transcendental eternal blissful form, or His variegated abode. They would have simply dis- missed these teachings and thus been deprived of the means to real- ize the self in its true relation with the totality. So, the first task in bridging the wide gap between voidism and theism was to reawaken people’s faith in the Vedas. It was for this purpose that SankarÄcÄ- rya introduced Advaitavada, a version of nondualism that made it possible to bridge this gap. Going from the Buddhist nÃ¤sti to the Advaitavada neti neti is a simple, incremental move from the categorical negation of the onto- logical or eternal substance underlying momentary appearances (there is no self-existent) to the negation of the ontological reality of individual appearances (the self-existent is not this, not this, not any of this). The difference between these two ideas is hardly notice- able. Still, because Sankara based his philosophy on the Upanisads, Vedanta-sutra, and other Vedic works, that one step was critical in bringing the populace back to accepting the authority of the Vedas. Later in Padma PurÄá¹‡a, Lord Siva himself describes AdvaitavÄda as veiled Buddhism: Advaitavada philosophy is a scriptural interpretation devoid of essentiality [or devoid of the essential existent]; indeed, it is veiled Buddhism. (Padma Purana, Uttara-khanda 236.7)” SankarÄcÄrya’s propounding of Advaitavada philosophy was intended by his Lord, the Supreme Person, who recognized that until conditioned human beings regained access to the Vedas, they could only speculate about transcendent reality and would be without a self-revealed means of deliverance from material existence. maya-vÄdam asac-chastram pracchanam bauddham ucyate 168 23 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is Luminous Like the Sun Once Advaita Vedanta had supplanted Buddhism, and faith in the Vedas had been re-established, people could be brought further along the path of knowledge to an appreciation for the glories of the Personal Absolute. This would be accomplished by counter- acting non-theism with true Vaisnava philosophy. Thus, stalwart Vaiá¹£á¹‡ava ÄcÄryas like RÃ¤mÃ¤nujÄcÄrya, MadhvÄcÄrya, and Vallab- hÄcÄrya came one after another to demonstrate the lack of ultimate completion of, and the limitations inherent within, Advaitavada. In its place they re-established the principles of pure devotional service as the true spirit and intent of the Vedas and its corollary scriptures. For his part, ÅšrÄ«dhara SvÄmÄ« made it possible for non- theistic VedÄntists to awaken a taste for Srimad Bhagavatam by writing a commentary that also appealed to them. Still later, the original Complete Person Himself came in the garb of a devotee, as ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a Caitanya Mahaprabhu, and extended the discussion even further. He taught that even more advanced than vaidhi-bhakti, the path of regulated devotional service, is rÃ¤ga-bhakti, the path of the direct infusion of self-existing and self- radiant devotion to Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a into the core of being (the atmÄ), which is made accessible by following in the footsteps of Vá¹›ndÄvana’s resi- dents. He taught that rÃ¤ga-bhakti, which is elaborately explained in the Tenth Canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, is the ultimate expression of prema, love of God. Since Caitanya Mahaprabhu is the original Supreme Absolute, who can contest His siddhanta? Rather, the gradual progression from voidism to radical nondualism to theistic nondualism and finally to rÃ¤ga-bhakti was precisely Bhagavan’s intention for the evolutionary unfolding of the Ultimate Truth of His own being. Through this unfolding, conditioned human beings are offered the possibility not only of liberation, but of participating with Bha- gavÃ¤n as He is, in His own completion and in His own essential being. Without a doubt, therefore, the Lord was not acting cruelly or capriciously when He instructed Lord Siva to appear as Sankara and spread the misleading doctrine of the individual atma’s abso- lute oneness with the Supreme. To the contrary, He did so out of His limitless mercy. 169 II PramaÅ†a In later anucchedas, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi will point out many incon- sistencies between Sankara’s teachings and the actual conclusion of the Vedas. In the next anuccheda, he shows us the glories of ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam as the Bhagavatam itself reveals them. 170 Anuccheda 24 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is the Cream of the Vedas 24.1 à¥¨à¥ª à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥‡à¤µ à¤•à¤¿à¤² à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥à¤µà¤¾ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤®à¤§à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤šà¤¾à¤°à¥à¤¯à¤šà¤°à¤£à¥ˆà¤°à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤·à¥à¤£à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤šà¥à¤›à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤°à¤£à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤°à¥€à¤¤à¤¿- à¤•à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¥‡à¤¶à¤¶à¤™à¥à¤•à¤¯à¤¾ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤‚ à¤²à¤¿à¤–à¤¦à¥à¤­à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤°à¥à¤®à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤š à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¤¾ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯- à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ DEVOTEES OF SRI VISÅ…U RECOUNT that Sri MadhvÄcÄrya-caraá¹‡a, seeing that [Åšri SankarÄcÄrya did not comment on Bhagava- tam out of respect for it] wrote BhÄgavata-tÄtparya, a gloss on Srimad Bhagavatam that specifies the true nature of the path of pure devotion, because he was concerned that other Vaisnavas might be influenced by the commentaries of other disciplic descendants of Sankara, such as that of Punyaranya. 24.2 1 à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥ªà¥§-à¥ªà¥¨ ) - For all these reasons, therefore, the following statements in the Bhagavatam are appropriate, as in the First Canto: à¤¤à¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¥‡à¤¤à¤¿à¤¹à¤¾à¤¸à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¸à¥à¤®à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¥ƒà¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥®à¥¬ à¥¥ Some editions have added sÄká¹£at tac-chiÅŸyatam prÃ¤ptair api after yad eva kila drstva. This reading is supported by ÅšrÄ« RÄdhamohana GosvÄmi, one of the commentators on Tattva Sandarbha. The followers of MadhvÄcÄrya, however, do not accept this view. Thus, we have opted for the present reading. 171 II PramÄÅ†a After extracting the cream of all the Vedas and ItihÄsas, Åšri Vya- sadeva imparted this Srimad Bhagavatam to His son Sukadeva, the best of those established in direct realization of the self. (SB 1.3.41)2 à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤¶à¥‡ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¨ à¥§à¥§à¥© à¥§à¥§à¥« ) - And in the Twelfth Canto: à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¸à¤¾à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¤à¥ƒà¤ªà¥à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥ à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¥¥ à¥®à¥­ à¥¥ Srimad Bhagavatam is indeed the essence of all Vedanta philos- ophy. He who is satiated by the nectar of its unprecedented taste (rasa) experiences no interest in any other literature. (SB 12.13.15)3 24.3 à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¥‡ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥§ à¥© ) - And in the First Canto: 3 à¤¨à¤¿à¤—à¤®à¤•à¤²à¥à¤ªà¤¤à¤°à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤—à¤²à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤«à¤²à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤ªà¤¿à¤¬à¤¤ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤°à¤¸à¤®à¤¾à¤²à¤¯à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥‹ à¤°à¤¸à¤¿à¤•à¤¾ à¤­à¥à¤µà¤¿ à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤•à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥®à¥® à¥¥ O you devotees, who are able to relish divine taste (rasikas) and who are able to experience transcendental states of awareness and love (bhÄvukas), drink again and again up to liberation. and beyond the divine rasa known as Srimad Bhagavatam, the mature fruit of the desire tree of Vedic literature. Being fully ripened and overflowing with immortal nectar, it descended upon the earth [unbroken], issuing from the lips of Sri Sukadeva GosvÄmi. (SB 1.1.3) tad idam grÃ¤hayÄmÄsa sutam atmavatÄm varam sarva-vedetihÄsÄnÄm saraá¹ sÃ¤raá¹ sumuddhá¹›tam sarva-vedanta-saram hi Å›ri-bhÄgavatam iÅŸyate tad-rasÄmá¹›ta-tá¹›ptasya nanyatra sydd ratiá¸¥ kvacit nigama-kalpa-taror galitam phalam suka-mukhad amá¹›ta-drava-samyutam pibata bhÄgavatam rasam alayam muhur aho rasika bhuvi bhÄvukÄá¸¥ 172 24 ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam Is the Cream of the Vedas à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤µ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥¨à¥§à¥© ) - Also in the same canto: à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤®à¤–à¤¿à¤²à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¦à¥€à¤ªà¤®à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¤à¤®à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤¸à¤¾à¤°à¤¿à¤£à¤¾à¤‚ à¤•à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¯à¤¾à¤¹ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤—à¥à¤¹à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¤à¤‚ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¸à¥‚à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥à¤ªà¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤‚ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¥ à¥®à¥¯ à¥¥ I take refuge of ÅšrÄ« Sukadeva, the teacher of all sages, the son of Vyasadeva, who, out of compassion for those entangled in the cycle of birth and death and who aspire to cross over the dense darkness of material existence, spoke this most confi- dential Purana [Åšrimad Bhagavatam], which is self-endowed with supramundane power, being the essence of all the Vedas, one without compare and the light of supreme transcendence. (SB 1.2.3)5 à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤®à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥€à¤¶à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¥‚à¤šà¤•à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤¨à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¸à¤­à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤®- à¤§à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥‹à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤µà¥‡à¤¨ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¤¾à¤‚ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¸à¥à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ These verses imply that the conclusion about reality embodied in Srimad Bhagavatam presides over all other philosophies. They also clearly indicate that ÅšrÄ« Sukadeva, by taking the speaker’s seat amidst the assembled sages as the BhÄgavatam’s preceptor, became the guru of everyone present. Commentary HERE, ÅšRILA JIVA GOSVAMI explains MadhvacÄrya’s reason for com- menting on Åšrimad Bhagavatam. ÅšaÅ„karÄcÄrya wrote poems glori- fying ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s pastimes as depicted in the Bhagavatam, but some of his followers, not understanding his true intention, took this as a license to try to include the Bhagavatam as part of the Advaita- vÃ¤da canon. Some of them even wrote commentaries on the BhÄga- vatam and somehow managed to extract an impersonal interpreta- tion. One such commentary was that of Punyaranya, which is now yaá¸¥ svanubhavam akhila-Å›ruti-saram ekam adhyatma-dipam atititirá¹£atam tamo’ndham samsariÅ†Äm karunayaha purana-guhyam tam vyÄsa-sunum upayÄmi guruá¹ munÄ«nÄm 173 II PramÄÅ†a lost. ÅšrÄ«la MadhvacÄrya, wanting to protect Vaisnavas from being misled, wrote a gloss called Bhagavata-tÄtparya. Since Jiva GosvÄmi has already shown that Srimad Bhagavatam is the topmost pramana, he can now cite it directly to demonstrate its own stature. Such citations serve only to increase a sincere reader’s faith in the Bhagavatam, and so from this point on, ÅšrÄ«la JÄ«va GosvÄmi relies on the Bhagavatam itself as the principal source for his analysis. Here, he also reveals the eminence that Srimad Bhaga- vatam enjoys by virtue of the status of its self-realized speaker, Åšukadeva GosvÄmi. Vyasadeva taught the Bhagavatam to Suka- deva, His most brilliant student, and Sukadeva chose to study the Bhagavatam, because the reality it discloses supersedes even that of Brahman. Although ÅšrÄ«la Vyasadeva had many disciples, He gave the Bhagavatam only to Sukadeva. Vyasa did this not because He was partial toward His son, but because Sukadeva was “the best of those established in direct realization of the Self” (Ã¤tmavatÄm varam). In other words, Sukadeva had no ulterior material motives, and could therefore understand the true purport of the Bhagavatam, which is the essence of the Vedas, Vedanta, and ItihÄsas. The most important part of a tree is its sweet juicy fruit, and so ÅšrÄ«mad Bhagavatam has been compared to the succulent fruit of the tree of Vedic literature. And this Bhagavatam fruit is even more exceptional because it has no skin or pit. In other words, there is nothing to discard in the Bhagavatam. In this anuccheda, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi quotes two texts from the BhÄgavatam, SB 1.1.3 and 1.2.3, to show its importance both for lib- erated devotees and for conditioned human beings, respectively. Because Sukadeva was completely free of selfish motives, he fully realized the BhÄgavatam’s significance and so was elected to speak, even in an assembly of learned sages that included his guru and his guru’s guru. The choice of Sukadeva as speaker implies that his qualifications for reciting Srimad Bhagavatam made him supe- rior to all the other assembled sages. This is one more indication that Srimad Bhagavatam is the foremost of scriptures and that it alone should be analyzed to determine the reality principles of 174 24 Åšrimad Bhagavatam Is the Cream of the Vedas sambandha, abhidheya, and prayojana. Next, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi fur- ther highlights the importance of the Bhagavata’s primary speaker, Sri Sukadeva GosvÄmi. 175Anuccheda 25 The Speaker of ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam, ÅšrÄ« Åšukadeva GosvÄmÄ«, Is the Crest-Jewel of Illuminated Sages 25.1 à¥¨à¥« à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¤ƒ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¯à¥¤à¥®-à¥§à¥¨ ) - THUS, it is said in Srimad Bhagavatam: à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹à¤ªà¤œà¤—à¥à¤®à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤µà¤¨à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾ à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¾ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¶à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¥‡à¤£ à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤—à¤®à¤¾à¤ªà¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤‚ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤¤à¥€à¤°à¥à¤¥à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¸à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¸à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤ à¤¶à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯à¤µà¤¨à¤ƒ à¤¶à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤°à¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¨à¥‡à¤®à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¥ƒà¤—à¥à¤°à¤™à¥à¤—à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤ªà¤°à¤¾à¤¶à¤°à¥‹ à¤—à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤¥ à¤°à¤¾à¤® à¤‰à¤¤à¤¥à¥à¤¯ à¤‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¤¦à¥‡à¤§à¥à¤®à¤µà¤¾à¤¹à¥Œ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥§ à¥¥ à¤®à¥‡à¤§à¤¾à¤¤à¤¿à¤¥à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤² à¤†à¤·à¥à¤°à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¿à¤·à¥‡à¤£à¥‹ à¤­à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤œà¥‹ à¤—à¥Œà¤¤à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤ªà¤²à¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤®à¥ˆà¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤¯ à¤”à¤°à¥à¤µà¤ƒ à¤•à¤µà¤·à¤ƒ à¤•à¥à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¯à¥‹à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¥à¤¦à¥à¤µà¥ˆà¤ªà¤¾à¤¯à¤¨à¥‹ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¨ à¥¥ à¤…à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¥‡ à¤š à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤µà¤°à¥à¤¯à¤¾ à¤…à¤°à¥à¤£à¤¾à¤¦à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤š à¥¤ à¤¨à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤µà¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¸à¤®à¥‡à¤¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤°à¥à¤šà¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤¾ à¤¶à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¤¾ à¤µà¤µà¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥‡ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥© à¥¥ à¤¸à¥à¤–à¥‹à¤ªà¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‡à¤·à¥à¤µà¤¥ à¤¤à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤­à¥‚à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤£à¤¾à¤®à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤šà¤¿à¤•à¥€à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¥¤ à¤µà¤¿à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤ªà¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¤¾à¤¸ à¤µà¤¿à¤µà¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤šà¥‡à¤¤à¤¾ à¤‰à¤ªà¤¸à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¥‹à¤½à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‡à¤½à¤­à¤¿à¤—à¥ƒà¤¹à¥€à¤¤à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥ª à¥¥ At that time, the sages endowed with extraordinary spiritual power, who purify the earth, arrived there, accompanied by their disciples. On the plea of making a pilgrim’s journey, such sages verily sanctify the places of pilgrimage simply by their presence. From different parts of the universe, there arrived great sages like Atri, Vasistha, Cyavana, SaradvÄn, Aristanemi, Bhrgu, AngirÄ, ParÄÅ›ara, ViÅ›vÄmitra, ParaÅ›urÄma, Utathya, Indrapramada, IdhmabÄhu, MedhÄtithi, Devala, Ä€rstisena, 176 25 The Speaker of Srimad Bhagavatam, ÅšrÄ« Sukadeva GosvÄmi, Is the Crest-Jewel of Illuminated Sages Bharadvaja, Gautama, PippalÄda, Maitreya, Aurva, KavaÅŸa, Kumbhayoni (Agastya), Dvaipayana, and the great personality Narada. There were also many other celestial sages, brÄhmaá¹‡a sages, royal sages, as well as sages who preside over particu- lar branches of the Vedas, such as Aruna. When the emperor [Pariká¹£it] beheld all the various orders of great sages assembled there, he received them with due honor and bowed his head to the ground. After all the rÅŸis were comfortably seated, the king, humbly standing before them with palms joined in supplication, offered obeisance to them once again and informed them of his intention to fast until death. (SB 1.19.8-12)1 à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¤®à¥ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¯à¥¤à¥¨à¥ª ) - Then the king inquired: à¤¤à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤µà¤ƒ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤®à¤‚ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¥‡ à¤µà¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤°à¤­à¥à¤¯ à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¤à¤¾à¤¯à¤¾à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¨à¤¾ à¤®à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¤®à¤¾à¤£à¥ˆà¤¶à¥à¤š à¤•à¥ƒà¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤¦à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤š à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤®à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¤à¤¾à¤­à¤¿à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥« à¥¥ Therefore, O brahmanas, reposing my faith in you, I ask you about that alone which is worthy of inquiry in the matter of ulti- mate duty. O learned sages, please tell me, after due delibera- tion, of the unalloyed duty of everyone in all circumstances, and specifically of those who are just about to die. (SB 1.19.24) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤ªà¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¤à¤¿ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§ à¥§à¥¯ à¥§à¥¨à¥« ) - Then, after the king’s query: tatropajagmur bhuvanam punÄna mahanubhava munayaá¸¥ sa-Sisyah prayena tirthabhigamapadeÅ›aiá¸¥ svayam hi tirthÃ¤ni punanti santaá¸¥ atrir vasisthas cyavanaá¸¥ Å›aradvan aristanemir bhrgur angiraÅ› ca paraÅ¡aro gadhi-suto’tha rama utathya indrapramadedhmavahau medhÃ¤tithir devala Ärá¹£á¹­iÅŸeá¹‡o bharadvajo gautamaá¸¥ pippalÄdaá¸¥ maitreya aurvaá¸¥ kavaá¹£aá¸¥ kumbhayonir dvaipayano bhagavan nÃ¤radas ca anye ca devarÈ™i-brahmarÅŸi-varyÃ¤ rajará¹£i-varyÄ aruá¹‡ÄdayaÅ› ca nÃ¤nÃ¤rÅŸeya-pravaran sametan abhyarcya rÄjÄ Å›irasÃ¤ vavande sukhopavistesv atha tesu bhÅ«yaá¸¥ ká¹›ta-praá¹‡Ämaá¸¥ sva-cikirá¹£itam yat vijÃ±ÄpayÄm Äsa vivikta-ceta upasthito’gre’bhigá¹›hita-pÄniá¸¥ 2 tataÅ› ca vaá¸¥ prcchyam imam viprcche viÅ›rabhya vipra iti ká¹›tyatÄyÄm sarvÃ¤tmana mriyamanais ca krtyam Suddham ca tatramá¹›Å›atÄbhiyuktÄá¸¥ 177 11 PramÄÅ†a à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¾à¤­à¤µà¤¦à¥ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤ªà¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥‹ à¤¯à¤¦à¥ƒà¤šà¥à¤›à¤¯à¤¾ à¤—à¤¾à¤®à¤Ÿà¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥‹à¤½à¤¨à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤…à¤²à¤•à¥à¤·à¥à¤¯à¤²à¤¿à¤™à¥à¤—à¥‹ à¤¨à¤¿à¤œà¤²à¤¾à¤­à¤¤à¥à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¥‹ à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š à¤¬à¤¾à¤²à¥ˆà¤°à¤µà¤§à¥‚à¤¤à¤µà¥‡à¤·à¤ƒ à¥¤à¥¤ à¥¯à¥¬ à¥¤à¥¤ At that moment appeared the venerable son of Vyasadeva, who traveled the earth at will, disinterested in the world and sat- isfied in the self alone. He bore no marks of belonging to any social order or status of life. He was surrounded by women and children, and he appeared like an avadhuta, an ascetic beyond the bounds of conventional moral [or cultural] sensibilities. (SB 1.19.25) 25.2 à¤¤à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤š â€œà¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¥à¤¥à¤¿à¤¤à¤¾à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡ à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¯à¤ƒ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¥‡à¤­à¥à¤¯à¤ƒ " ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¯à¥¤à¥¨à¥®) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥‡ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥§à¥¯à¥¤à¥©à¥¦ ) - After this: “The sages all rose from their seats to honor him” (SB 1.19.28). And finally: à¤¸ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¥ƒà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤®à¤¹à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¹à¥€à¤¯à¤¸à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¬à¥à¤°à¤¹à¥à¤®à¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤°à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤¸à¤™à¥à¤˜à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤°à¥‹à¤šà¤¤à¤¾à¤²à¤‚ à¤­à¤—à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‡à¤¨à¥à¤¦à¥à¤°à¥à¤—à¥à¤°à¤¹à¤°à¥à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¤¾à¤°à¤¾à¤¨à¤¿à¤•à¤°à¥ˆà¤ƒ à¤ªà¤°à¥€à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥­ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ à¥¥ The eminent Sukadeva GosvÄmi, greatest among the great, was then surrounded by brahmana sages, royal sages, and celes- tial sages. He thus appeared extraordinarily resplendent, just like the moon surrounded by planets, constellations, and stars. (SB 1.19.30)5 Commentary AFTER Åšá¹šNGI CURSED MAHARAJA PARIKá¹¢IT, the king renounced his kingdom and took a vow to fast until death on the bank of the tatrabhavad bhagavan vyasa-putro yadá¹›cchaya gam atamano’napeká¹£aá¸¥ alaká¹£ya-lingo nija-labha-tusto vá¹›tas ca balair avadhuta veÅŸaá¸¥ *pratyutthitas te munayah svasanebhyas 5 sa samvá¹›tas tatra mahan mahiyasam brahmará¹£i-rajará¹£i-devarsi-sanghaiá¸¥ vyarocatalaá¹ bhagavan yathendur graharkÅŸa-tara-nikaraiá¸¥ paritaá¸¥ 178 25 The Speaker of Srimad Bhagavatam, ÅšrÄ« Sukadeva GosvÄmi, Is the Crest-Jewel of Illuminated Sages Ganges. At that time, sages of all classes and orders came from various parts of the universe and assembled there. Among them were even avataras of the Lord, like Parasurama and Vyasadeva. When Pariká¹£it MahÄrÄja inquired from them about the duties of a human being, especially one who is about to die, no one was able to give him a definitive answer. At that time, the most noble Suka- deva GosvÄmÄ« arrived, and he was unanimously chosen as the right person to answer MahÄrÄja ParÄ«ká¹£it’s query. In the previous anuccheda, Jiva GosvÄmÄ« said that all the sages accepted Sukadeva as guru. In this section, Jiva GosvÄmÄ« cites the references to support his claim. Since the sages accepted Sukadeva as guru, and it was Srimad Bhagavatam that he spoke in response to ParÄ«ká¹£it MahÄrÄja’s questions, we should understand that the Bhagavatam’s philosophy was accepted by all the assembled sages, who included systematizers and adherents of various other philoso- phies. Just as ÅšrÄ«la Sukadeva GosvÄmi is like an effulgent moon among the starlike sages, so is Åšrimad Bhagavatam among all other scriptures. Next, ÅšrÄ«la Jiva GosvÄmi shows that Srimad Bhagavatam is the representation of ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, the Supreme Personal Absolute. 179 Anuccheda 26 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is Self-Authoritative 26.1 à¥¤ à¥¨à¥¬ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤° à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¥Œ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤—à¥à¤°à¥‚ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾à¤ªà¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¨à¥à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¨à¤¿à¤ƒ- à¤¸à¥ƒà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¯à¥‹à¤°à¤ªà¥à¤¯à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤šà¤°à¤®à¤¿à¤µ à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤¶à¥à¤•à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤µà¤ªà¥à¤¯à¥à¤ªà¤¦à¤¿à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶ à¤¦à¥‡à¤¶à¥à¤¯à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤­à¤¿- à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¯à¤ƒ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¦à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ â€œà¤¶à¥à¤•à¤®à¥à¤–à¤¾à¤¦à¤®à¥ƒà¤¤à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¸à¤‚à¤¯à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥â€ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§ à¥¤ à¥§ à¥¤ à¥©) à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤®à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾- à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¤ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¥€à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤§à¤¿à¤•à¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥‚à¤¯à¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¿à¤•à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¹à¥‹ à¤•à¤¿à¤‚ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤¨à¤¾ ? à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¤à¤¿à¤¨à¤¿à¤§à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤®à¥‡à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤®à¥ à¥¤ ÅšRI VYASADEVA AND NARADA MUNI were present in that assem- bly. Although these two sages were ÅšrÄ« Å›uka’s guru and grand- guru, respectively, when they heard Srimad Bhagavatam issuing from his lips, they felt as if they had never heard it before. For this reason it is said here that he taught this most significant wisdom even to them. As mentioned earlier, “The BhÄgavatam is enriched with immortal nectar, having issued from the mouth of ÅšrÄ« Å›ukaâ€ (Å›uka-mukhÄd amrta-drava-sanyutam, SB 1.1.3). Thus, in this sense also Srimad Bhagavatam surpasses all other scrip- tures. Statements about the superiority of other PurÄÅ†as, such as the Matsya PurÄÅ†a, are relative in scope. What more need be said? Åšrimad Bhagavatam is indeed the very representation of Åšri Krsna. 26.2 à¤¯à¤¤ à¤‰à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¥‡ (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥¤à¥©à¥¤à¥ªà¥« ) -

180 26 Srimad BhÄgavatam Is Self Authoritative This is stated in the First Canto: à¤•à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤£à¥‡ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤§à¤¾à¤®à¥‹à¤ªà¤—à¤¤à¥‡ à¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤œà¥à¤à¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤­à¤¿à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤•à¤²à¥Œ à¤¨à¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤¦à¥ƒà¤¶à¤¾à¤®à¥‡à¤· à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤°à¥à¤•à¥‹ à¤§à¥à¤¨à¥‹à¤¦à¤¿à¤¤à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥® à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ After Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a’s departure to His own abode, accompanied by reli- gion, knowledge, and so on, this PurÄna [ Srimad BhÄgavatam ] has risen like the sun for those bereft of sight in the age of Kali. (SB 1.3.43 ) ’ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤—à¥à¤£à¤¯à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤®à¤¸à¥à¤¯à¥ˆà¤µ à¤¦à¥ƒà¤·à¥à¤Ÿà¤®à¥ â€œà¤§à¤°à¥à¤®à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¥‹à¤œà¥à¤à¤¿à¤¤à¤•à¥ˆà¤¤à¤µà¥‹à¤½à¤¤à¥à¤°” (à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥§à¥¤à¥¨) à¤‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¦à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾- In this way, it is observed that Srimad Bhagavatam alone is inher- ently endowed with all virtues, as stated in the second verse of the First Canto: “This Srimad Bhagavatam reveals the sup- reme dharma, utterly devoid of all deception or compromise” (SB 1.1.2).2 à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¾à¤ƒ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤‚ à¤•à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤‚ à¤š à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤­à¥à¤°à¥à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¿à¤¯à¥‡à¤µ à¤š à¥¤ à¤¬à¥‹à¤§à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¥€à¤¤à¤¿ à¤¹à¤¿ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤¹à¥à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤µà¥ƒà¤¦à¥ à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤¨à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥¯à¥¯ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤«à¤²à¥‡ à¤¹à¥‡à¤®à¤¾à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤¿à¤•à¤¾à¤°à¤µà¤šà¤¨à¥‡à¤¨ à¤š à¥¤ The supremacy of the Bhagavatam is also confirmed by the words of both MuktÄ phala [of Vopadeva] and HemÄdri, its com - mentator: â€œThe Vedas, PurÄnas, and poetic works instruct one like a master, friend, and beloved, respectively, but Srimad BhÄgavatam enlightens in all three capacities.“3 26.3 à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥ à¤®à¤¨à¥à¤¯à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤¾à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤•à¥‡à¤šà¤¿à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤¾à¤¨à¥à¤¤à¤°à¥‡à¤·à¥ à¤µà¥‡à¤¦à¤¸à¤¾à¤ªà¥‡à¤•à¥à¤·à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤­à¤¾à¤—à¤µà¤¤à¥‡ à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¥à¤¾ à¤¸à¤®à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤¨à¤¾ 1 krsÅ†e sva-dhÄmopagate dharmajÃ±ÄnÄdibhih saha kalau nasta-dá¹›Å›Äm esa purÄá¹‡Ärko’dhunoditaá¸¥ 2 dharmah projjhita-kaitavo’tra “vedaá¸¥ puraá¹‡am kavyarh ca prabhur mitram priyeva ca bodhayantiti hi prÃ¤hus trivá¹›d bhÄgavatam punah ‘This verse is found in Hari-hilÄmyta (1.9) of Vopadeva and not in MuktÄ-phala. 181 II PramÄÅ†a à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤¨à¤¿à¤°à¤¸à¥à¤¤à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¤¿ à¤¸à¥à¤µà¤¯à¤®à¥‡à¤µ à¤²à¤¬à¥à¤§à¤‚ à¤­à¤µà¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ à¤…à¤¤ à¤à¤µ à¤ªà¤°à¤®à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤°à¥‚à¤ªà¤¤à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¤à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¥¤ à¤¯à¤¥à¥‹à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤®à¥ ( à¤­à¤¾à¥¦ à¥§à¥§à¥ªà¥§à¥­) - Consequently, while some scholars conclude that other PurÄnas are dependent upon the Vedas to derive their authority, Åšrimad BhÄgavatam explicitly refutes the possibility that it may be dependent in this way; rather, the Bhagavatam stands on its own authority. For this reason it is in fact the highest manifestation of Åšruti [the original Vedas]. As it is said: à¤•à¤¥à¤‚ à¤µà¤¾ à¤ªà¤¾à¤£à¥à¤¡à¤µà¥‡à¤¯à¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤°à¤¾à¤œà¤°à¥à¤·à¥‡à¤°à¥à¤®à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤¨à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¹ à¥¤ à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¤ƒ à¤¸à¤®à¤­à¥‚à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¤¾à¤¤ à¤¯à¤¤à¥à¤°à¥ˆà¤·à¤¾ à¤¸à¤¾à¤¤à¥à¤µà¤¤à¥€ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥à¤¤à¤¿à¤ƒ à¥¥ à¥§à¥¦à¥¦ à¥¥ à¤‡à¤¤à¤¿ à¥¤ How did King ParÄ«ká¹£it happen to converse with this great sage, as a result of which this Vedic text (Å›ruti) for the pure Vaisnavas (sÄtvati) became available? (SB 1.4.7)4 à¤…à¤¥ à¤¯à¤¤à¥ à¤–à¤²à¥ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£à¤œà¤¾à¤¤à¤®à¤¾à¤µà¤¿à¤°à¥à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤¾à¤¦à¤¿à¤•à¤‚ à¤ªà¥‚à¤°à¥à¤µà¤®à¥à¤•à¥à¤¤à¤‚ à¤¤à¤¤à¥ à¤¤à¥ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¥à¤®à¤¸à¥à¤•à¤¨à¥à¤§à¤—à¤¤à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€à¤µà¥à¤¯à¤¾- à¤¸à¤¨à¤¾à¤°à¤¦à¤¸à¤‚à¤µà¤¾à¤¦à¥‡à¤¨à¥ˆà¤µ à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤®à¥‡à¤¯à¤®à¥ à¥¥ That Srimad Bhagavatam was compiled after the other PurÄÅ†as, as mentioned earlier (Anuccheda 19), is known from the dialogue between ÅšrÄ« Vyasa and Narada Muni in the First Canto. Commentary VEDIC TRADITION RECOGNIZES three ways of teaching-like a ruler, like a friend, and like a lover. The Vedas speak in the imper- ative voice, like an overlord: “Speak the truth and uphold dharma” (satyam vada dharmam cara, TU 1.11). The Vedas do not need to offer logical reasons for following their instructions. One is expected to obey without question. The Puranas instruct like a friend, narrat- ing stories with moral conclusions and providing reasoned expla- nations when required. Kavya, or poetic literature, offers counsel in the way of a lover, speaking sweetly but indirectly. Instructions 4 katham vÄ pÄá¹‡á¸aveyasya rajarÅŸer muninÄ saha samvadaá¸¥ samabhÅ«t tÄta yatraiá¹£Ä sÄtvati Å›rutiá¸¥ 182 26 ÅšrÄ«mad BhÄgavatam Is Self-Authoritative are expressed in an aesthetically pleasing way to attract the reader or hearer. Åšrimad Bhagavatam uses all three of these methods to convey its teachings. Just as a phrase or song becomes more significant when an eminent person quotes or sings it, so the Bhagavatam has been increased in distinction because the eminent Sukadeva GosvÄmi recited it. He narrated the Bhagavatam in such a marvelous way that both his guru, ÅšrÄ«la Vyasadeva, and his param guru (the guru of his guru), ÅšrÄ« NÄrada Muni, were amazed. They felt as if they had never heard it before. The customary etiquette is that a disciple should neither accepta higher seat than his teachers nor instruct others as an authority in their presence. Sukadeva GosvÄmi’s speaking Åšrimad Bhagavatam in the presence of his gurus is one of the rare exceptions. Because his gurus consented to it, however, ÅšrÄ« Suka is faultless, as ÅšrÄ«la ViÅ›vanatha Cakravarti Thakura points out in his commentary on SB 1.17.29, which describes Suka’s accepting the speaker’s seat. From the narrations of the Mahabharata, we learn that Narada and Vyasa were often called upon to address various audiences on the subjects of karma, yoga, and jÃ±Äna. They rarely had an oppor- tunity to hear such an extraordinarily pure Bhagavata discourse. So, they were moved to great ecstasy when the nectarlike juice of topics concerning Bhagavan issued from the lips of ÅšrÄ« Suka, their qualified disciple. Åšrimad Bhagavatam’s special greatness is thus due to its unpar- alleled author, its eminent speaker, and its elevated audience. No other scripture in recorded history has ever had such an audience, except perhaps when Grandfather Bhisma, after the Kuruká¹£etra War, instructed King Yudhisthira from his bed of arrows. Bhisma’s main purpose, however, was to convince Yudhisthira to begin managing his kingdom. By contrast, Åšrimad Bhagavatam was spoken in just the oppo- site context: King ParÄ«ká¹£it, having renounced his kingdom, simply wanted to hear ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a-katha and in this way discharge the only duty of a dying man. Åšri Sukadeva thus had no need to dilute his nar- ration with talk of lower religious principles. Therefore, ÅšrÄ«mad 183 II PramÄÅ†a Bhagavatam is the most perfect and complete transcendental scripture. It does not even depend on the support of the Vedas. Indeed, the sunlike Srimad Bhagavatam is the very representa- tion of ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. In the opening chapter of the Bhagavata PurÄá¹‡a, ÅšrÄ« Saunaka asked SÅ«ta GosvÄmi: Since ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, the master of yoga, the well-wisher of the brahma- nas, and the protector of dharma has departed for His own abode, please tell us where dharma is now sheltered. (SB 1.1.23)5 In response to this, SÅ«ta GosvÄmi spoke verse SB 1.3.44, cited in the text above. The fact that the Bhagavata Purana has arisen like the sun in the absence of ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a indicates that it embodies the same essential quality of being as Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a. This fact is confirmed in the Skanda Purana (ViÅŸnu-khanda 6.4.3) and the Padma Purana (Uttara- khanda 198.30). Bhagavan possesses all supreme qualities, as ÅšrÄ«la RÅ«pa GosvÄmi confirms in Bhakti-rasÄmá¹›ta-sindhu: ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a, who is the original complete Absolute Truth, Svayam Bhagavan, is the crest jewel of all heroes. All wonderful qualities are eternally present in Him. (BRS 2.1.17) Since Srimad Bhagavatam is nondifferent from Krsna, it is also a reservoir of all auspicious qualities. When ÅšrÄ« Ká¹›á¹£á¹‡a appeared, He killed many powerful miscreants of demonic nature and pro- tected His saintly devotees. In the same way, the BhÄgavata Purana uproots the material ungodly desires from the heart and there instills devotion to the Lord through its ambrosial narrations. Other scriptures focus on conventional morality, dualistic or result- oriented religiosity, liberation as merging in unqualified Brahman, or yoga, and they may or may not say something about the transcen- dental path of love of God.
